{{Use British English|date=July 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox referendum | name = United Kingdom Alternative Vote referendum | title = At present, the UK uses the "first past the post" system to elect MPs to the House of Commons. Should the "alternative vote" system be used instead? | location = [[United Kingdom]] | date = {{start date|2011|05|05|df=yes}} | no = 13013123 | yes = 6152607 | total = 19279022 | electorate = 45684501 | map = United Kingdom AV referendum area results.svg | mapdivision = local voting areas }} {{UK Referendums}} [[File:Greater London UK district map 2011-05-05 referendum.png|thumb|right|Results, Greater London UK district]] The '''United Kingdom Alternative Vote referendum''', also known as the '''UK-wide referendum on the Parliamentary voting system''' was held on Thursday 5 May 2011 (the same date as local elections in many areas) in the [[United Kingdom]] (UK) to choose the method of electing MPs at subsequent general elections as part of the [[Conservative – Liberal Democrat Coalition Agreement]] drawn up after the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]] which had resulted in the first [[hung parliament]] since [[United Kingdom general election, February 1974|February 1974]] and also indirectly in the aftermath of the [[United Kingdom parliamentary expenses scandal|2009 expenses scandal]] under the provisions of the [[Parliamentary Voting System and Constituencies Act 2011]] and was the first national referendum to be held under provisions laid out in the [[Political Parties, Elections and Referendums Act 2000]].
The [[referendum]] concerned whether or not to replace the present "[[First-past-the-post voting|first-past-the-post]]" system with the "[[Instant-runoff voting|alternative vote]]" (AV) method and was the first national referendum to be held across the whole of the United Kingdom in the twenty first century. The proposal to introduce AV was overwhelmingly rejected by 67.9% of voters on a national turnout of 42%.
This was only the second UK-wide referendum to be held (after the [[United Kingdom European Communities membership referendum, 1975|EC referendum back in 1975]]) and is to date the only UK-wide referendum to be held on an issue not related to the [[European Union|European Economic Community (Common Market) or European Union]] and was also the first UK-wide referendum to be overseen by the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]]. It was also the first that was not merely [[Public consultation|consultative]]: it committed the government to give effect to its decision.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2011/1/section/8/enacted|title=Parliamentary Voting System and Constituencies Act 2011: Section 8|last=|first=|date=|website=www.legislation.gov.uk|publisher=|access-date=2016-12-06}}</ref>
All registered electors over 18 ([[British citizen|British]], [[Irish citizen|Irish]] and [[Commonwealth citizen|Commonwealth]] citizens living in the UK and enrolled British citizens living outside)<ref name="ECbooklet">{{cite web|title=Local elections and Referendum|url=http://www.aboutmyvote.co.uk/PDF/England-accessible.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410141102/http://www.aboutmyvote.co.uk/PDF/England-accessible.pdf#|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 April 2011|work=[[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]]|year=2011|accessdate=8 April 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> – including Members of the [[House of Lords]] (who cannot vote in UK general elections) – were entitled to take part.
On a turnout of 42.2 per cent, 68 per cent voted "No" and 32 per cent voted "Yes". Ten of the 440 local voting areas recorded 'Yes' votes above 50 per cent: those in Oxford, Cambridge, Edinburgh Central and Glasgow Kelvin, with the remaining six in London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2011/1/section/2 |title=Parliamentary Voting Systems and Constituencies Act 2011, Section 2(1)(b) |publisher=Legislation.gov.uk |date=13 April 2011 |accessdate=18 April 2011}}</ref>
The campaign was described in retrospect by political scientist Iain McLean as a "bad-tempered and ill-informed public debate".<ref>McLean, I. (2012), "[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1477-7053.2011.01352.x/full ‘England Does Not Love Coalitions’: The Most Misused Political Quotation in the Book]", ''Government and Opposition'', Vol. 47, No. 1, pp. 3–20. [[Digital object identifier|doi]]: [http://doi.org/10.1111/j.1477-7053.2011.01352.x 10.1111/j.1477-7053.2011.01352.x]</ref>
{{TOC limit}}
==History==
===Historical context=== {{Main|Electoral reform in the United Kingdom}}
The Alternative Vote and the [[single transferable vote]] (STV) for the House of Commons were debated in Parliament several times between 1917 and 1931 and came close to being adopted. Both the Liberals and [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] at various times supported a change from non-transferable voting to AV or STV in one-, two- and three-member constituencies. STV was adopted for the [[University constituency|university seats]] (which were abolished in 1949).<ref>Butler DE (1953), "The Electoral System in Britain 1918–1951", Oxford University Press</ref> Both AV and STV involve voters rank ordering preferences. However, STV is considered to be a form of [[proportional representation]], using multi-member constituencies, while AV, in single-member constituencies, is not.<ref>Taagepera, R. and Shugart, M. S. (1989): Seats and Votes. The Effects and Determinants of Electoral Systems. Yale University Press, New Haven.</ref>
In 1950 all constituencies became single-member and all votes non-transferable.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politicsresources.net/area/uk/ge50/results.htm|title=UK General Election 1950: voting results and statistics [Archive]|work=politicsresources.net}}</ref> From then until 2010, the Labour and [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] parties, the two parties who formed [[List of British Governments|each government of the United Kingdom]] normally by virtue of an overall majority in the Commons, always voted down proposals for moving away from this uniform "[[First-past-the-post voting|First-past-the-post]]" (FPTP) voting system for the Commons.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} Other voting systems were introduced for various other British elections. STV was reintroduced in Northern Ireland and list-PR introduced for European elections except in Northern Ireland.
While out of power, the Labour Party set up a working group to examine electoral reform. The resulting [[Plant Commission]] reported in 1993 and recommended the adoption, for Commons elections, of the [[supplementary vote]], the system used to elect the London Mayor.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/plant-commission-moves-towards-pr-labour-working-party-wants-first-past-post-system-for-electing-mps-scrapped-1452577.html Plant commission moves towards PR: Labour working party wants 'first past post' system for electing MPs scrapped], by Patricia Wynn Davies, ''The Independent'', 1 April 1993</ref> Labour's 1997 manifesto committed the party to a referendum on the voting system for the Commons and to setting up an independent commission to recommend a proportional alternative to FPTP to be put in that referendum.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.labour-party.org.uk/manifestos/1997/1997-labour-manifesto.shtml/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020821164207/http://www.labour-party.org.uk/manifestos/1997/1997-labour-manifesto.shtml# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 August 2002 |title=1997 Labour Party Manifesto |publisher=Labour-party.org.uk |date=1 January 1999 |accessdate=18 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
After winning the 1997 General Election, the new Labour government consequently set up the [[Jenkins Commission (UK)|Jenkins Commission]] into electoral reform, supported by the Liberal Democrats, the third party in British politics in recent years and long supporters of proportional representation. (The Commission chair, [[Roy Jenkins]], was a Liberal Democrat peer and former Labour minister.) The commission reported in September 1998 and proposed the novel [[alternative vote top-up|alternative vote top-up or AV+ system]]. Having been tasked to meet a "requirement for broad proportionality",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.archive.official-documents.co.uk/document/cm40/4090/terms.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020917082440/http://www.archive.official-documents.co.uk/document/cm40/4090/terms.htm# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 September 2002 |title=The Report of the Independent Commission on the Voting System: Terms of Reference |publisher=Archive.official-documents.co.uk |accessdate=12 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> the Commission rejected both FPTP, as the status quo, and AV as options. It pointed out (chapter 3, para 21) that "the single-member constituency is not an inherent part of the British parliamentary tradition. It was unusual until 1885...Until [then] most seats were two-member..." (the English system established in 1276). Jenkins rejected AV because "so far from doing much to relieve disproportionality, it is capable of substantially adding to it".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.archive.official-documents.co.uk/document/cm40/4090/chap-5.htm#c5-a |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20021217012514/http://www.archive.official-documents.co.uk/document/cm40/4090/chap-5.htm#c5-a#c5-a |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 December 2002 |title=The Report of the Independent Commission on the Voting System: Chapter 5, Sections 81–85 |publisher=Archive.official-documents.co.uk |accessdate=12 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> AV was also described as "disturbingly unpredictable" and "unacceptably unfair".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/mar/14/alternative-vote-electoral-reform|title=AV won't improve our electoral system {{!}} David Rowntree|last=Rowntree|first=David|date=2011-03-14|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-07-03}}</ref>
However, legislation for a referendum was not put forward. Proportional systems were introduced for the new [[Scottish Parliament]] and Welsh and London Assemblies, and the supplementary vote was introduced for mayoral elections. With [[House of Lords Act 1999|House of Lords reform in 1999]], AV was introduced to [[By elections to the House of Lords|elect replacements]] for the remaining 92 hereditary peers who sit in the [[House of Lords|Lords]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-12400281 Landale Online: Rebellious peers to use AV voting], by James Landale, BBC News, 9 February 2011</ref>
At the next General Election in 2001, the Labour manifesto stated that they would review the experience of the new systems (in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland) and the Jenkins report, to assess the possibility of changes to the Commons, which would still be subject to a referendum.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.labour-party.org.uk/manifestos/2001/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020829224049/http://www.labour-party.org.uk/manifestos/2001/# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=29 August 2002 |title=2001 Labour Party Manifesto |publisher=Labour-party.org.uk |accessdate=18 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Electoral reform in the Commons remained at a standstill, although in the Scottish Parliament, a coalition of Labour and the Liberal Democrats introduced STV for local elections in Scotland.
===Pre-election=== In February 2010, the Labour Government, which had been in power since 1997, used their majority to pass an amendment to their [[Constitutional Reform Act 2005|Constitutional Reform Bill]] to include a referendum on the introduction of AV to be held in the next Parliament, citing a desire to restore trust in Parliament in the wake of the [[United Kingdom Parliamentary expenses scandal|2009 expenses scandal]].<ref name=BBC9Feb2010MPsBackReferendum/> A Liberal Democrat amendment to hold the referendum earlier, and on STV,<ref>[http://main.hop.lbi.co.uk/documents/commons/lib/research/briefings/snpc-05317.pdf AV and electoral reform]{{dead link|date=February 2017}}, by Isobel White, House of Commons Library</ref> was defeated by 476 votes to 69.<ref name=BBC9Feb2010MPsBackReferendum/> There was insufficient time remaining in the term of that Parliament for the Bill to become law before Parliament was dissolved; and so the move was dismissed by several Conservative and Liberal Democrat MPs as a political manoeuvre.<ref name=BBC9Feb2010MPsBackReferendum/>
In the ensuing 2010 general election campaign, the Labour manifesto supported the introduction of AV via a referendum, to "ensure that every MP is supported by the majority of their constituents voting at each election".<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110102200613/http://blogs.independent.co.uk/2010/12/29/a-blank-sheet-of-paper/ A "blank sheet of paper"?], by John Rentoul, 29 December 2010</ref> The Liberal Democrats argued for proportional representation, preferably by single transferable vote, and the Conservatives argued for the retention of FPTP. Both the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats proposed reducing the number of MPs, while the Conservative Party argued for more equal sized constituencies.
===Election outcome to Queen's Speech=== The 2010 General Election held on 6 May resulted in a [[hung parliament]], the first since 1974, leading to a period of negotiations. Honouring a pre-election pledge, the Liberal Democrat leader [[Nick Clegg]] entered into negotiations with the Conservatives as the party who had won most votes and most seats. [[William Hague]] offered the Liberal Democrats a referendum on the Alternative Vote as part of a "final offer" in the Conservatives' negotiations for a proposed "full and proper" coalition between the two parties.<ref name=BBC10May2010HagueFinalOffer/> Hague and Conservative leader [[David Cameron]] said that this was in response to Labour offering the Liberal Democrats the Alternative Vote without a referendum, although it later emerged that Labour had not made such an offer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/newsnight/michaelcrick/2010/07/was_the_coalition_built_on_a_l.html|title=BBC - Newsnight: Michael Crick: Was the coalition built on a lie?|work=bbc.co.uk}}</ref> Negotiations between the Liberal Democrats and Labour quickly ended.<ref name=BBC10May2010HagueFinalOffer/> On 11 May 2010, Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] stepped down, followed by the establishment of a full coalition government between the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats. David Cameron became Prime Minister and Liberal Democrat leader Nick Clegg became Deputy Prime Minister.
The initial [[Conservative – Liberal Democrat Coalition Agreement]], dated 11 May 2010, detailed the issues which had been agreed between the two parties before they committed to entering into coalition. On the issue of an electoral reform referendum, it stated:
{{pull quote|The parties will bring forward a Referendum Bill on electoral reform, which includes provision for the introduction of the Alternative Vote in the event of a positive result in the referendum, as well as for the creation of fewer and more equal sized constituencies. Both parties will whip their Parliamentary Parties in both Houses to support a simple majority referendum on the Alternative Vote, without prejudice to the positions parties will take during such a referendum.<ref name=BBC12May2010CoalitionAgreementText/>}}
Following the agreement between the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, with the new coalition government now formed, a commitment to the referendum was included in the coalition government's [[Queen's Speech]] on 25 May 2010 as the Parliamentary Reform Bill, although with no date set for the referendum.<ref name=BBC25May2010QueensSpeechBills/>
The coalition agreement committed both parties in the government to "[[Whip (politics)|whip]]" their Parliamentary parties in both the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] and [[House of Lords]] to support the bill, thereby ensuring that it could reasonably be expected to be passed into law due to the simple majority in the Commons of the combined Conservative – Liberal Democrat voting bloc. The Lords can only delay, rather than block, a Bill passed by the Commons.
===Passage through Parliament=== According to ''[[The Guardian]]'', reporting after the Queen's Speech, unnamed pro-referendum Cabinet members were believed to want the referendum held on 5 May 2011, to coincide with elections to the Scottish parliament, the Welsh assembly and many English local councils. Nick Clegg's prior hope of a referendum as early as October 2010 was considered unrealistic due to the parliamentary programme announced in the speech.<ref name=Guardian25May2010LibDemPush/>
On 5 July 2010, Clegg announced the detailed plans for the Parliamentary Reform Bill in a statement to the House of Commons, as part of the wider package of voting and election reforms set out in the coalition agreement, including setting the referendum date as 5 May 2011.<ref name=BBC5July2010CleggOutlines/><ref name=CleggCommonsStatement5July2010/> In addition to a referendum on AV, the reform bill also included the other coalition measures of reducing and resizing the [[Constituencies in the United Kingdom general election, 2010|Westminster parliamentary constituencies]], introducing fixed term parliaments and setting the date of the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|next general election]] as 7 May 2015, changing the voting threshold for early [[Dissolution of the Parliament of the United Kingdom|dissolution of parliament]] to 55%, and providing for the [[Recall election|recall]] of MPs by their constituents.<ref name=Number10ParliamentaryReformBill25May2010/>
The plans to hold the vote on 5 May faced criticism from some Conservative MPs as distorting the result because turnout was predicted to be higher in those places where local elections were also held. It also faced criticism from Scottish, Welsh and Northern Irish MPs for the effects it would have on their devolved elections on the same day, while Clegg himself faced further criticism from Labour, and implied lessening support from Liberal Democrat MPs, for backing down on earlier Liberal Democrat positions on proportional representation.<ref name=BBC5July2010CleggFacesAnger/> Clegg defended the date, stating the referendum question was simple and that it would save £17m in costs.<ref name=BBC5July2010CleggAnnouncesDate/> Over 45 MPs, mostly Conservatives, signed a motion calling for the date to be moved.<ref name=BBCNews7Sep2010/> In September 2010, [[Ian Davidson (Scottish politician)|Ian Davidson]] MP, chairman of the Commons Scottish affairs select committee, stated after consultation with the Scottish Parliament that there was "unanimous" opposition among [[Member of the Scottish Parliament|Members of the Scottish Parliament]] (MSPs) to the referendum date, following the "chaos" of the combined 2007 Scottish [[Scottish Parliament election, 2007|parliament]] and [[Scottish local elections, 2007|council]] elections.<ref name=BBC30Sep2010ScotsPoliticiansOpposeDate/>
On 22 July 2010, the proposal for fixed term parliaments was put before parliament as the [[Fixed-term Parliaments Bill]], while the proposals for the AV referendum, change in dissolution arrangements and equalising constituencies were put forward in the [[Parliamentary Voting System and Constituencies Bill]], which accordingly had three parts: Part 1, Voting system for parliamentary elections; Part 2, Parliamentary constituencies; and Part 3, Miscellaneous and general.<ref name=BBC22Jul2010QuestionPublished/><ref name=PVSAndConstBill22Jul2010/> The Bill contained the text of a proposed referendum question.<ref name=BBC22Jul2010QuestionPublished/>
The original proposed question in English was:<ref>[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201011/cmbills/063/2011063.pdf Parliamentary Voting Systems and Constituencies Bill] as introduced (House of Commons Bill 63 of Session 2010–12).</ref>
{{pull quote|'''Do you want the United Kingdom to adopt the "alternative vote" system instead of the current "first past the post" system for electing Members of Parliament to the House of Commons?'''}}
In Welsh:
{{pull quote|'''Ydych chi am i'r Deyrnas Unedig fabwysiadu'r system "bleidlais amgen" yn lle'r system "first past the post" presennol ar gyfer ethol Aelodau Seneddol i Dŷ'r Cyffredin?'''}}
permitting a simple '''YES''' / '''NO''' answer (to be marked with a single (X)).
This wording was criticised by the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]], saying that "particularly those with lower levels of education or literacy, found the question hard work and did not understand it". The Electoral Commission recommended a changed wording to make the issue easier to understand,<ref name=BBC30Sep2010QuestionTooHard/> and the government subsequently amended the Bill to bring it into line with the Electoral Commission's recommendations.<ref name=Bill26SessionDec2010/>
The Bill passed an interim vote in the Commons on 7 September 2010 by 328 votes to 269.<ref name=BBCNews7Sep2010/>
An amendment proposed in the Lords by [[Jeff Rooker, Baron Rooker|Lord Rooker]] ([[Independent (politician)|Independent]]) to require a minimum turn-out of 40% for the referendum to be valid was supported by Labour, a majority of cross-benchers and ten rebel Conservatives, and was passed by one vote.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://services.parliament.uk/LordsDivisionsAnalysis/session/2010_11/division/20110207 |title=Lords Divisions Analysis |publisher=United Kingdom Parliament |accessdate=24 February 2011}}{{dead link|date=February 2017}}</ref> Labour's 2010 AV referendum proposal had not included such a threshold and they were criticised for seeking to impose one for this referendum, while the [[Welsh devolution referendum, 2011|2011 Welsh referendum]], held under a Bill passed by Labour, also had no threshold<ref name=newsnight>''Newsnight'', BBC2, 16 February 2011</ref> (and would have failed if it had had one, as turnout in that referendum was only 35%). In the latter hours of debate, a "game" of [[parliamentary ping-pong]] saw the Commons overturning the threshold amendment before it was reimposed by the Lords, and then removed again.<ref name="Go ahead">{{cite news|title=Referendum on voting system goes ahead after Lords vote|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-12485084|work=BBC News|date=17 February 2011|accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref>
After some compromises between the two Houses on amendments, the Bill was passed into law on 16 February 2011.<ref name="Go ahead"/>
==Legislation== The [[Parliamentary Voting System and Constituencies Act 2011]] provides for the holding of the referendum, and the related changes had it led to the adoption of AV. Passing the bill into law was a necessary measure before the referendum could actually take place.<ref name=BBC22Jul2010QuestionPublished/> It received [[Royal Assent]] from [[Elizabeth II]] on 16 February 2011.<ref name="Go ahead"/>
The Act has the following long title:<ref name=PVSAndConstBill22Jul2010/>
{{pull quote|An Act to make provision for a referendum on the voting system for parliamentary elections and to provide for parliamentary elections to be held under the alternative vote system if a majority of those voting in the referendum are in favour of that; to make provision about the number and size of parliamentary constituencies; and for connected purposes}}
=== Referendum question===
Based on the coalition agreement, the referendum was a [[majority|simple majority]] yes/no question as to whether to replace the current [[First Past the Post]] (FPTP) electoral system used in [[United Kingdom general elections overview|general elections]] with the [[Instant-runoff voting|Alternative Vote]] (AV) system.
The question posed by the referendum was:<ref name=Bill26SessionDec2010/>
{{Quotation| '''At present, the UK uses the "first past the post" system to elect MPs to the House of Commons. Should the "alternative vote" system be used instead?''' }}
In [[Wales]], the question on the [[ballot paper]] also appeared in [[Welsh language|Welsh]]:
{{Quotation| '''Ar hyn o bryd, mae'r DU yn defnyddio'r system "y cyntaf i’r felin" i ethol ASau i Dŷ'r Cyffredin. A ddylid defnyddio’r system "pleidlais amgen" yn lle hynny?''' }}
permitting a simple '''YES''' / '''NO''' answer (to be marked with a single (X)).
==Administration== The referendum took place on 5 May 2011, coinciding with [[United Kingdom local elections, 2011|various United Kingdom local elections]], the [[Scottish Parliament election, 2011|2011 Scottish Parliament election]], the [[National Assembly for Wales election, 2011|2011 Welsh Assembly election]] and the [[2011 Northern Ireland Assembly election]].<ref name=BBC5July2010CleggOutlines/> The deadline for voters in England, Wales and [[Northern Ireland]] to [[Elections in the United Kingdom#Registration procedure|register to vote]] in the referendum was midnight on Thursday 14 April 2011, whilst voters in [[Scotland]] had until midnight on Friday 15 April 2011 to register. Anyone in the United Kingdom who qualified as an [[anonymous elector#United Kingdom|anonymous elector]] had until midnight on Tuesday 26 April 2011 to register.<ref>The deadline for the receipt and determination of anonymous electoral registration applications was the same as the publication date of the notice of alteration to the Electoral Register (i.e. the fifth working day before election day).</ref> In the vote count, the referendum ballots in England, Scotland and Wales were counted after the various election ballots, from 4 pm on 6 May 2011.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-12012813 AV voting referendum count delayed until next day], BBC News, 16 December 2010</ref> The referendum had no minimum threshold on the required turnout needed for the result to be valid.<ref name="Go ahead"/>
Anyone on the [[Electoral Register]] and eligible to [[Elections in the United Kingdom#Entitlement to register|vote in a general election]] was entitled to vote in the referendum.<ref name="ECbooklet"/> This includes British citizens living outside the UK who were registered as overseas electors. In addition, Members of the House of Lords, who are not eligible to vote in a general election, were entitled to vote in the referendum, provided they were entitled to vote in local elections.
==Campaign positions==
===Political parties=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !width="120 pt"|Political parties' position on the referendum !For a Yes vote (introduce AV) !No official party position !For a No vote (retain FPTP) |- |Parties elected to the House of Commons |nowrap|[[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]]<br />[[Scottish National Party]]<br />[[Sinn Féin]]<br />[[Plaid Cymru]]<br />[[Social Democratic and Labour Party]]<br />[[Green Party of England and Wales]]<br />[[Alliance Party of Northern Ireland]] |nowrap|[[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] |nowrap|[[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]]<br />[[Democratic Unionist Party]] |- |Parties elected to the European Parliament or regional assemblies / parliaments |nowrap|[[United Kingdom Independence Party|UKIP]]<br />[[Scottish Green Party|Scottish Green]] | |nowrap|[[British National Party]]<br />[[Ulster Unionist Party]]<br />[[Green Party in Northern Ireland]] |- |Minor parties |nowrap|[[Liberal Party (UK, 1989)|Liberal Party]]<br />[[Mebyon Kernow]] <br />[[English Democrats]]<br />[[Christian Party (UK)|Christian Party]]<br />[[Christian Peoples Alliance]]<br />[[Pirate Party UK]]<br />[[United Kingdom Libertarian Party]] |nowrap|[[Socialist Party of Great Britain]]<br />[[Monster Raving Loony Party]] |nowrap|[[Traditional Unionist Voice]]<br />[[Respect Party]]<br />[[Communist Party of Britain]]<br />[[Socialist Party (England and Wales)|Socialist Party]]<br />[[Alliance for Workers' Liberty]] |}
====Coalition parties==== The coalition partners campaigned on opposite sides, with the Liberal Democrats supporting AV and the Conservatives opposing it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2010/07/03/cameron-will-campaign-against-changes-to-the-voting-system-91466-26777028/ |title=News – Wales News – Cameron will campaign against changes to the voting system |publisher=WalesOnline |accessdate=6 August 2010|date=2010-07-02 }}</ref>
Despite the Conservative Party's formal position, party members aligned to the Conservative Action for Electoral Reform, an [[ginger group|internal party group]] in favour of electoral reform, campaigned in favour,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.conservativeelectoralreform.org/Media/14-05-2010.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429034811/http://www.conservativeelectoralreform.org/Media/14-05-2010.htm# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=29 April 2011 |title=Conservative Action for Electoral Reform – Press Release |date=14 May 2010 |access-date=13 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> while a BBC News report described "some Tory MPs" as being "relaxed" about a yes result.<ref name=WherePartiesStand>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-11609887 AV referendum: Where parties stand], BBC News, 13 January 2011</ref> Some Conservatives campaigned in favour of AV, ''e.g.'' [[Andrew Boff]] AM;<ref>Letters: The debate over AV rages on, ''The Evening Standard'', 19 April 2011</ref> and Andrew Marshall, former head of the Conservative Group on [[London Borough of Camden|Camden Council]].<ref>[http://www.camdennewjournal.com/news/2011/jan/conservatives-are-divided-they-get-ready-may-referendum-electoral-reforms ‘AV’ makes sure every vote counts], by Andrew Marshall, ''[[Camden New Journal]]'', 13 January 2011</ref> The Conservative party uses a system of successive ballots to elect its leader,<ref name=ConservativeLeader>{{Cite journal|publisher=House of Commons Library |url=http://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/SN01366 |title=Leadership Elections: Conservative Party |format=PDF |date= 2016-07-11|accessdate=2017-01-05|last1=Maer |first1=Lucinda |last2=Johnston |first2=Neil }}</ref> which has been described as a "form of AV" (since the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated in each round),<ref name="guardian1"/> but unlike AV, the candidates are not ranked in order of preference during each ballot.
====Other parties represented in the House of Commons==== The previous [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] government sought to introduce AV before the 2010 general election. [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2010|Labour elected a new leader]] after the general election and almost all of the leadership candidates supported AV, including winner [[Ed Miliband]];<ref>[[Ed Balls]] on ''[[Newsnight]]'', 25 May 2010</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2010/07/03/condem-coalition-to-apend-80million-on-voting-reform-115875-22378551/ |title=ConDem coalition to apend £80million on voting reform |work=Daily Mirror |location=UK |accessdate=6 August 2010|date=2010-07-02 }}</ref><ref name="squareeye1">{{cite web|url=http://clients.squareeye.com/uploads/compass/documents/LawsonSocialism.web.pdf |title=Socialism is Democracy Why Labour Must Support Electoral Reform |publisher=Compass |date= 8 October 2010}}{{dead link|date=February 2017}}</ref> [[Andy Burnham]] was the sole leadership contender who was more critical of the referendum.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2010/0703/1224273901021.html |title=Voting reform poll to coincide with devolved elections – The Irish Times – Sat, 3 July 2010 |publisher=The Irish Times |date=3 July 2010 |accessdate=6 August 2010}}</ref> The party has, however, voiced opposition to the bill currently providing for the referendum, on the grounds of the inclusion of [[Boundary Commissions (United Kingdom)#Changes to boundary review legislation 2010|boundary changes]] that are viewed as beneficial to the Conservative Party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ukelectiontrend.blogspot.com/2010/07/labour-support-av-oppose-av-bill.html |title=Labour Support AV, Oppose the AV Bill |publisher=UK Election Trend |accessdate=16 August 2010}}</ref>
[[Plaid Cymru]] supported AV, but did not take an active role in the campaign, as it focused on separate Welsh votes on the same day.<ref name=WherePartiesStand/> The [[Scottish National Party]], while maintaining its long standing support for PR-STV, also supported a Yes vote in the referendum.<ref name=WherePartiesStand/> Both of these parties opposed the planned referendum date, as they did not want it held at the same time as the [[National Assembly for Wales election, 2011|2011 Welsh Assembly elections]] and the [[Scottish Parliament election, 2011|2011 Scottish Parliament elections]] respectively.<ref name=BBCNews7Sep2010/>
Among the Northern Irish parties, the [[Alliance Party of Northern Ireland|Alliance Party]] and the [[Social Democratic and Labour Party]] (SDLP) supported AV.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-11193145 |title=BBC News – Northern Ireland parties divided on electoral reform |publisher=BBC |date=6 September 2010 |accessdate=16 September 2010}}</ref> SDLP leader [[Margaret Ritchie (politician)|Margaret Ritchie]] announced that her party would actively campaign in favour.<ref>{{cite web|author=7 July 2010 at 13:30 |url=http://www.irishdigest.com/?p=8799 |title=SDLP leader says alternative vote system 'a step forward' |publisher=IrishDigest.com |date=6 July 2010 |accessdate=6 August 2010}}</ref> [[Sinn Féin]] also supported a Yes vote, but the [[Democratic Unionist Party]] supported a No vote.<ref name=bbcni>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-politics-13051074 NI parties divided over Alternative Vote referendum], by Mark Davenport, BBC News, 13 April 2011</ref>
The [[Green Party of England and Wales]] voted in favour of joining the campaign for AV in the referendum at its September 2010 party conference. Many leading figures in the party supported the change as a step towards their preferred system, [[proportional representation]].<ref name=green>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenparty.org.uk/News/conference-av-campaign-adrian-ramsay.html |title=Greens to campaign for AV |publisher=Green Party of England and Wales |date=13 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918052119/http://www.greenparty.org.uk/News/conference-av-campaign-adrian-ramsay.html |archivedate=18 September 2010 }}</ref> Previously, the party's leader and only MP, [[Caroline Lucas]], had called for a referendum that included a choice of proportional representation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ekklesia.co.uk/node/12090 |title=Green Party leader says real voting reform is an absolute must |publisher=Ekklesia |accessdate=6 August 2010}}</ref> But at their Conference, Deputy Leader [[Adrian Ramsay]] argued that "If you vote No in this referendum, nobody would know whether you were rejecting AV because you wanted genuine reform, or were simply opposing any reform."<ref name=green/>
====Minor parties==== The [[United Kingdom Independence Party]]'s National Executive Committee formally announced that it would be supporting Alternative Vote, although they would prefer a proportional system.<ref name="UKIP and electoral reform poll">[https://web.archive.org/web/20110429195721/http://www.ukip.org/content/westminster/2140-ukip-and-electoral-reform-poll UKIP and electoral reform poll], UK Independence Party, 17 February 2011</ref> An e-mail was sent to members informing them that they may vote against AV, but are not allowed to campaign.<ref name=WherePartiesStand/><ref>{{cite web|title=UKIP and Electoral Reform Poll|url=http://www.ukip.org/content/westminster/2140-ukip-and-electoral-reform-poll|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429195721/http://www.ukip.org/content/westminster/2140-ukip-and-electoral-reform-poll#|dead-url=yes|archive-date=29 April 2011|access-date=24 February 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The [[British National Party]] supports proportional representation and has criticised AV as not being proportional.<ref>{{cite web|title=Under True Proportional Representation, the BNP Would Have 12 Seats|url=http://www.bnp.org.uk/news/under-true-proportional-representation-bnp-would-have-12-seats|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706151912/http://www.bnp.org.uk/news/under-true-proportional-representation-bnp-would-have-12-seats#|dead-url=yes|archive-date=6 July 2010|access-date=18 October 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> They supported a 'No' vote.<ref name=WherePartiesStand/>
The [[Respect Party]] also supported proportional representation and campaigned against AV.<ref name=WherePartiesStand/> Rob Hoveman, on behalf of Tower Hamlets Respect, wrote to the ''[[East London Advertiser]]'' on 24 February 2011 urging a 'No' vote on the grounds that the AV system created an even greater imbalance between votes and seats, and urging a proportional system instead.<ref>"Alternative vote won't make polls fairer" (letter), ''East London Advertiser'', p. 19.</ref>
The [[Scottish Green Party]] also supported AV, although it prefers the adoption of STV for all elections.<ref name=WherePartiesStand/><ref>{{cite web|last=Greens |first=Edinburgh |url=http://www.edinburghgreens.org.uk/site/campaigns/yes-to-av/ |title=Yes To Av |publisher=Edinburghgreens.org.uk |accessdate=18 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110919235659/http://www.edinburghgreens.org.uk/site/campaigns/yes-to-av/ |archivedate=19 September 2011 }}</ref>
The [[Ulster Unionist Party]] and [[Traditional Unionist Voice]] supported a No vote.<ref name=bbcni/> The [[Green Party in Northern Ireland]] also opposed the change to AV, as they viewed it as a betrayal of proportional representation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://brianwilsonmla.blogspot.com/2010/10/green-party-votes-to-oppose-alternative.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708025829/http://brianwilsonmla.blogspot.com/2010/10/green-party-votes-to-oppose-alternative.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=8 July 2011 |title=Brian Wilson Mla: Green Party Votes To Oppose Alternative Vote In Referendum |publisher=Brianwilsonmla.blogspot.com |date=25 October 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2011}}</ref>
The [[English Democrats]],<ref name=WherePartiesStand/> [[Christian Peoples Alliance]]<ref name=WherePartiesStand/> and the [[Christian Party (UK)|Christian Party]] all support AV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/christian.party.welcomes.referendum.on.electoral.reform/26228.htm |title=Christian Party welcomes referendum on electoral reform, Christian News on Christian Today |publisher=Christiantoday.com |date=5 July 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2011}}</ref> [[Pirate Party UK]] endorsed a Yes vote, with over 90% of members expressing support for AV.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pirates Overwhelmingly Endorse AV|url=http://www.pirateparty.org.uk/blog/2010/nov/28/pirates-overwhelmingly-endorse-av/}}</ref>
The [[Liberal Party (UK, 1989)|Liberal Party]] agreed to support the 'Yes' campaign, seeing AV as "a potential 'stepping stone' to further reform" and STV.<ref name=liberalparty>{{cite web|title=The Liberal Party – Yes to Fair Votes|url=http://www.liberal.org.uk/elections/av.htm|publisher=The Liberal Party|accessdate=22 April 2011}}</ref>
The [[Communist Party of Britain]] opposed AV.<ref name=WherePartiesStand/>
[[Mebyon Kernow]], the Cornish nationalist party, favoured proportional representation and was disappointed that the referendum did not give voters that option.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mebyonkernow.org/?q=news/245 |title=The Party for Cornwall, BETA |publisher=Mebyon Kernow |accessdate=18 April 2011}}</ref> However, leader [[Dick Cole (politician)|Dick Cole]] announced on 1 April 2011 that Mebyon Kernow would be supporting the Yes campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mebyonkernow.blogspot.com/2011/04/my-view-on-av.html|title=Cllr Dick Cole: My View on AV |publisher=Dick Cole |accessdate=25 April 2011}}</ref>
The [[United Kingdom Libertarian Party]] favoured AV<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lpuk.org/2011/04/av-whats-the-alternative/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521083332/http://lpuk.org/2011/04/av-whats-the-alternative/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 May 2011 |title=AV- What's The Alternative? |publisher=Libertarian Party |date=14 April 2011 |accessdate=18 April 2011}}</ref> as a slight improvement on first past the post.
The [[Socialist Party of Great Britain]] adopted a neutral position, arguing "what matters more is what we use our votes for" in the context of class struggle.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Socialist Party of Great Britain |url=http://www.worldsocialism.org/spgb/altvote.html |title=The Alternative Vote AV |publisher=Worldsocialism.org |accessdate=18 April 2011}}{{dead link|date=February 2017}}</ref>
The [[Socialist Party (England and Wales)|Socialist Party]] opposed AV, pointing out that it is not more proportional than First Past the Post.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Socialist Party |url=http://www.socialistparty.org.uk/articles/11892/20-04-2011/the-alternative-vote-referendum-5-may |title=The Alternative Vote referendum – 5 May A 'miserable little compromise'?|publisher=socialistparty.org.uk |accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref>
The [[Alliance for Workers' Liberty]] opposed AV, arguing that it did not offer progress on the party's main democratic demands.<ref>[http://www.workersliberty.org/story/2011/04/20/democracy-yes-av-no "Democracy, yes! AV, no!"], ''[[Solidarity (newspaper)|Solidarity]]''</ref>
====Politicians==== Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] of the Conservative Party and Deputy Prime Minister [[Nick Clegg]] of the Liberal Democrats made speeches backing the 'No' and 'Yes' campaigns respectively on the same day, but were thereafter not expected to take much part in the campaigns,<ref name=colinhelena/> although both were active since. Cameron described AV as "undemocratic, obscure, unfair and crazy."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-12934509|title=David Cameron: Alternative vote is a 'crazy, undemocratic system'|publisher=BBC News|date=1 April 2011|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref> He was praised for his intervention by back-bench Conservative MPs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2011/may/05/av-campaign-david-cameron-praised|title=No to AV campaign wins David Cameron plaudits from backbench MPs |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=5 May 2011|accessdate=6 May 2015|newspaper=The Guardian |last1=Watt |first1=Nicholas |last2=Correspondent |first2=Chief Political }}</ref>
Former Labour foreign secretary [[Margaret Beckett]] was president of the No to AV campaign.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
Labour leader [[Ed Miliband]] said he would take an active part in the 'Yes' campaign,<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/feb/16/alternative-vote-disconnect-politicians-people Why the alternative vote gets my vote], Ed Miliband, ''The Guardian'', 16 February 2011</ref> while Wales's First Minister and Welsh Labour Leader [[Carwyn Jones]]<ref>[https://archive.is/20120914155948/http://www.thisissouthwales.co.uk/news/Leader-pledges-new-way-voting-MPs/article-3165339-detail/article.html Welsh First Minister throws weight behind plans for Alternative Vote in Westminster], by Helen Keates, This is South Wales, 1 February 2011</ref> and Scottish Labour Leader [[Iain Gray]] both also supported AV.<ref name=snp/> Also supporting the Yes campaign were over 50 Labour MPs including [[Alan Johnson]], [[Peter Hain]], [[Hilary Benn]], [[John Denham (politician)|John Denham]], [[Liam Byrne]], [[Sadiq Khan]], [[Tessa Jowell]], [[Ben Bradshaw]], [[Douglas Alexander]],<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-11953443 Labour figures back campaign to change voting system], BBC News, 8 December 2010</ref> [[Alistair Darling]],<ref name=labourlist>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110127044600/http://www.labourlist.org/labour-mps---are-they-yes-or-no-to-av Labour MPs – are they Yes or No to AV? Yes – 78 No – 108], by Mark Ferguson, 10 February 2011</ref> [[Diane Abbott]] and [[Debbie Abrahams]].<ref name=labouryeslist>[http://labouryes.org.uk/uncategorized/kinnock-joins-labour-yes-campaign-as-it-continues-to-build-momentum/#more-369 Kinnock joins Labour Yes campaign as it continues to build momentum]{{dead link|date=February 2017}}, Labour Yes to Fairer Votes</ref> Labour peers supporting the 'Yes' campaign include [[Lord Mandelson]], [[Oona King]], Raymond Plant (chair of Labour's 1993 working group on electoral reform), [[Andrew Adonis]], [[Anthony Giddens]], former Labour leader [[Neil Kinnock]], former deputy leader [[Roy Hattersley]] and [[Glenys Kinnock]],<ref>[https://archive.is/20120712041246/http://labouryes.org.uk/uncategorized/boost-from-the-red-benches-as-peers-say-yes/ Boost from the red benches as Peers say Yes], Labour Yes! to Fairer Votes</ref> while further Labour figures supporting AV included former [[Mayor of London]] [[Ken Livingstone]],<ref name=labouryeslist/> [[Michael Cashman]] MEP, [[Tony Benn]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110223171632/http://labouryes.org.uk/why-vote-yes/labour-yes-endorsers/ Labour Yes Endorsers], Labour Yes! to Fairer Votes</ref> and former Labour council candidate and wife of [[Speaker of the House of Commons (United Kingdom)|the Speaker]] [[Sally Bercow]].<ref>"Sally gets the vote, even if John doesn't", ''The Evening Standard'', 23 December 2010, p. 16</ref>
The Liberal Democrats supported a Yes vote and many individual Liberal Democrat politicians were active in the Yes campaign. The SNP leader, [[Alex Salmond]], supported a Yes vote.<ref name=snp>[http://news.scotsman.com/politics/Salmond-likely-to-say-yes.6721176.jp Salmond likely to say 'yes' to AV system], by Nick Eardley, ''The Scotsman'', 20 February 2011</ref> UKIP are supporting a Yes vote and their principal spokesmen on the campaign will be [[William Legge, 10th Earl of Dartmouth|William Dartmouth]] MEP and party leader, [[Nigel Farage]] MEP.<ref name="UKIP and electoral reform poll"/>
Supporting the [[NOtoAV|No campaign]] were both senior Conservative (including [[William Hague]], [[Ken Clarke]], [[George Osborne]], [[Theresa May]], [[Philip Hammond]], [[Steve Norris]] and [[Baroness Warsi]])<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20101126020901/http://labourlist.org/labour-no-campaign-gains-party-heavyweights Labour NotoAV campaign gains party heavyweights], by Mark Ferguson, LabourList</ref> and Labour politicians (including [[John Prescott]], [[David Blunkett]], [[John Reid, Baron Reid of Cardowan|John Reid]], [[Tony Lloyd]], [[John Healey (politician)|John Healey]], [[Caroline Flint]], [[Hazel Blears]], [[Beverley Hughes]], [[Paul Boateng]], [[John Hutton (Labour MP)|John Hutton]] and [[Lord Falconer]]).<ref name="autogenerated1"/> The Conservative Party announced that seven MPs ([[Conor Burns]], [[George Eustice]], [[Sam Gyimah]], [[Kwasi Kwarteng]], [[Charlotte Leslie]], [[Priti Patel]], [[Chris Skidmore]]) and two former candidates (Chris Philp, Maggie Throup) would act as party spokesmen in the No campaign.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2011/feb/25/ed-miliband-alternative-vote-nick-clegg?CMP=twt_fd Ed Miliband warns against Nick Clegg becoming poster boy for AV], by Patrick Wintour, ''The Guardian'', 25 February 2011</ref> Overall, most Labour MPs supported the No campaign rather than the Yes campaign, with other notable opponents of AV including [[Paul Goggins]], [[Ann Clwyd]], [[Gerald Kaufman|Sir Gerald Kaufman]], [[Austin Mitchell]], [[Margaret Hodge]], [[Lindsay Hoyle]], [[Jim Fitzpatrick (politician)|Jim Fitzpatrick]], [[Dennis Skinner]] and [[Keith Vaz]].<ref name=labourlist/> Also supporting a No vote were crossbencher and former SDP leader [[Lord Owen]], who supported the No to AV But Yes to PR campaign.<ref>[http://www.no2av-yes2pr.org/03/lord-david-owen/ No to AV, Yes to PR], Letter, 10 March 2011</ref>
Conservative politician [[Michael Gove]] was initially mistakenly announced by the No to AV campaign as opposing AV, but his advisers stated that he had never been involved in the campaign and had not yet made up his mind.<ref name="autogenerated2"/> Over five Labour MPs announced as opposing AV were also found to have been wrongly included:<ref name="leftfootforward.org"/><ref>[http://www.examiner.co.uk/news/local-west-yorkshire-news/2010/12/31/huddersfield-mp-barry-sheerman-denies-signing-up-for-anti-alternative-vote-campaign-86081-27911012/ Huddersfield MP Barry Sheerman denies signing up for anti-alternative vote campaign], Barry Gibson, 31 December 2010</ref> for example, [[Alun Michael]] is supporting a 'Yes' vote,<ref name="leftfootforward.org">[http://www.leftfootforward.org/2011/01/no2av-campaign-gaffe/ No2AV campaign start 2011 with another gaffe], LeftFootForward, 5 January 2011</ref> while [[Meg Hillier]] did not lend her name to either campaign.<ref>[http://www.thenews.coop/news/Politics/1969 'No' campaign’s apology to Co-op MP], Co-operative News, 28 January 2011</ref>
Some Conservative politicians did support AV, including John Strafford, a former member of the Conservative Party's national executive, who chaired the Conservative campaign in favour of a Yes vote.<ref>Toby Helm and Andrew Sparrow (6 March 2011). [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/mar/06/alternative-voting-row-campaign-sacking Voting reform gets personal with attack on Tory campaigner]. ''The Observer''. Retrieved 16 November 2014.</ref>
===Other organisations===
====AV campaigning organisations==== Two campaign groups were established in response to the proposed referendum, one on each side of the debate. [[NOtoAV]] was established to campaign against the change to the Alternative Vote<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.no2av.org/ |title=NO2AV |publisher=NO2AV |accessdate=16 September 2010}}</ref> and [[YES! To Fairer Votes]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yestofairervotes.org/ |title=Yes! To Fairer Votes |publisher=Yes! To Fairer Votes |accessdate=18 April 2011}}</ref> was established to campaign in favour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yestofairervotes.org/ |title=Vote yes to AV on 5 May 2011 |publisher=Yes to fairer votes |accessdate=16 September 2010}}</ref>
====Political reform groups==== [[Take Back Parliament]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.takebackparliament.com/ |title=Take Back Parliament |publisher=Take Back Parliament |accessdate=6 August 2010}}</ref> the [[Electoral Reform Society]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.electoral-reform.org.uk/news.php?ex=0&nid=478 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101006023827/http://www.electoral-reform.org.uk/news.php?ex=0&nid=478# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 October 2010 |title=Electoral Reform Society |publisher=Electoral-reform.org.uk |date=2 July 2010 |accessdate=6 August 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Make My Vote Count,<ref>{{cite web|author=Make Votes Count |url=http://www.makemyvotecount.org.uk/news.html |title=Campaign News |publisher=Make My Vote Count |accessdate=6 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100709142526/http://www.makemyvotecount.org.uk/news.html |archivedate=9 July 2010 }}</ref> and [[Unlock Democracy]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unlockdemocracy.org.uk/ |title=Unlock Democracy |publisher=Unlock Democracy |date=2 July 2010 |accessdate=6 August 2010}}</ref> all campaigned in favour of the change to AV.
====Trade unions==== The [[GMB Union]] opposes the change to AV. It provided "substantial" sums of money to the No campaign and marshalled its members to vote No.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/gmb-joins-tory-right-in-campaign-against-vote-reform-2040853.html |title=GMB joins Tory right in campaign against vote reform – UK Politics, UK |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=1 August 2010 |accessdate=6 August 2010 | first=Matt | last=Chorley}}</ref> Unions generally supported the No campaign, with only [[Billy Hayes (trade unionist)|Billy Hayes]], general secretary of the [[Communication Workers Union (UK)|Communication Workers' Union]], supporting AV.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/uk-politics-12706074|title=AV referendum: Union stance 'depressing', says Johnson|publisher=BBC News|date=11 March 2011|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref>
====Think tanks==== [[Compass (think tank)|Compass]] supported the change to the AV and urged the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] to do so too.<ref name="squareeye1"/><ref>[http://www.opendemocracy.net/ourkingdom/neal-lawson/democracy-by-machines-or-morals-why-av-referendum-matters-to-left Democracy by machines or morals? Why the AV referendum matters to the Left], by Neal Lawson, OurKingdom, 15 April 2011</ref> It prefers a switch to a more proportional system, but viewed AV as superior to FPTP. [[ResPublica]] supported the change to AV and urged the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] to do so too.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.respublica.org.uk/blog/2010/06/av-only-option-21st-century-conservatives |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100618131428/http://www.respublica.org.uk/blog/2010/06/av-only-option-21st-century-conservatives# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=18 June 2010 |title=AV: The Only Option for 21st Century Conservatives? |publisher=ResPublica |access-date=13 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Policy Exchange]] opposed the change to AV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.policyexchange.org.uk/images/publications/pdfs/Alternative_Vote_-_Oct_10.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716140135/http://www.policyexchange.org.uk/images/publications/pdfs/Alternative_Vote_-_Oct_10.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-07-16 |title=The Alternative Vote – the system no‐one wants |date=October 2010 |publisher=Policy Exchange}}</ref> [[Ekklesia (think tank)|Ekklesia]] supported the change to AV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ekklesia.co.uk/node/13809 |title=Supporting the Case for Fairer Votes |publisher=Ekklesia.co.uk |accessdate=12 March 2011|date=2010-12-20 }}</ref>
A report by the [[Institute for Public Policy Research]] in January 2011 was very critical of FPTP's flaws,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110118011713/http://www.ippr.org/publicationsandreports/publication.asp?id=798 Worst of Both Worlds: Why First Past the Post no longer works], by G Lodge & G Gottfried, IPPR, 4 January 2011</ref> while a report in April 2011 came down in support of AV over FPTP.<ref>[http://www.ippr.org.uk/publicationsandreports/publication.asp?id=814 The Right Alternative? Assessing the case for the Alternative Vote], by Guy Lodge and Glenn Gottfried, IPPR, 18 April 2011</ref> However, the IPPR also previously called for a wider choice in the referendum and favours [[Alternative Vote Plus]] over FPTP or AV.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ippr.org/pressreleases/?id=4050 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110416032321/http://www.ippr.org/pressreleases/?id=4050# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 April 2011 |title=ippr calls for wider referendum on voting reform |publisher=IPPR |date=5 July 2010 |access-date=13 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
====Academics==== A number of academics entered the debate, either in mainstream media or through blogs and social networking.
Those in favour of AV included [[Timothy Gowers]] ([[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gowers.wordpress.com/2011/04/20/is-av-better-than-fptp/|title=Is AV better than FPTP? |accessdate=27 April 2012|date=2011-04-20 }}</ref> [[David Held]] (LSE), [[Patrick Dunleavy]] (LSE), and [[Helen Margetts]] ([[Oxford University|Oxford]]),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yestofairervotes.org/blog/entry/academics-speak-out-for-fairer-votes/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128082039/http://www.yestofairervotes.org/blog/entry/academics-speak-out-for-fairer-votes# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 January 2011 |title=Academics Speak Out for Fairer Votes |publisher=Yestofairervotes.org |accessdate=13 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Thom Brooks]] ([[Newcastle University]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://the-brooks-blog.blogspot.com/2011/05/vote-yes-to-av.html |title=Vote "Yes" to AV |publisher=Thom Brooks|date=2011-05-03 }}</ref> Alastair McMillan ([[University of Sheffield|Sheffield]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://canvas.union.shef.ac.uk/wordpress/?p=884 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813034417/http://canvas.union.shef.ac.uk/wordpress/?p=884 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-08-13 |title=Debate: Vote Yes on 05 May |publisher=Canvas}}</ref> and Ben Saunders ([[University of Stirling|Stirling]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bensaunders.blogspot.com/2011/04/leaning-towards-av-though-it-wouldnt-be.html |title=Leaning Towards AV |publisher=Ben Saunders}}</ref>
Dan Felsenthal (LSE) criticised AV as "deeply flawed", though he also described it as "a minor improvement on the current first-past-the-post system".<ref>[http://www.politics.co.uk/news/legal-and-constitutional/academics-attack-av-$21378545.htm Academics Attack AV], by Ian Dunt, politics.co.uk, 27 May 201</ref>
David S. Moon ([[University of Sheffield|Sheffield]]) argued that AV would be worse than FPTP, though he regards both as flawed and supports a move to [[proportional representation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://canvas.union.shef.ac.uk/wordpress/?p%3D891 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223212604/http://canvas.union.shef.ac.uk/wordpress/?p%3D891 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 February 2017 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=4 May 2011 }}</ref>
At a March 2011 Voting Power in Practice annual workshop, held at the [[London School of Economics]] (LSE), 22 voting theory specialists voted to select the "best voting procedure" to elect a candidate from a selection of three or more. First past the post received no votes, compared to 10 for AV, although another system, [[Approval Voting]] (not on offer in the referendum), received 15 votes.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20101221081409/http://www2.lse.ac.uk/CPNSS/projects/VPP/Home.aspx Voting Power and Procedures], LSE, March 2011</ref>
On 11 March, 29 historians, including [[Niall Ferguson]], [[Simon Sebag Montefiore]], [[Andrew Roberts (historian)|Andrew Roberts]] and [[David Starkey]], wrote to the Times expressing opposition to the adoption of the Alternative Vote.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}

To Fairer Votes |publisher=Yes! To Fairer Votes |accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref> as do the [[Joseph Rowntree Reform Trust]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jrrt.org.uk/index.php?page=grants-awarded |title=Joseph Rowntree Reform Trust: Grants Awarded |publisher=Jrrt.org.uk |accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref> Operation Black Vote, the [[New Economics Foundation]], [[38 Degrees]] and bassac.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yestofairervotes.org/pages/supporting-organisations |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101228005226/http://www.yestofairervotes.org/pages/supporting-organisations# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 December 2010 |title=Supporting Organisations |publisher=Yes! to Fairer Votes |accessdate=12 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Educational trust [[The Constitution Society]] has also worked to increase public awareness of the issues involved in the debate.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.re-constitution.org.uk/news/articles/90/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110507033041/http://www.re-constitution.org.uk/news/articles/90/# |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 May 2011 |title=re:Constitution – What do you think? :: News |publisher=Re-constitution.org.uk |accessdate=13 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
