Retrieved 10 December 2016. to [[Far-right politics|far-right]]}} | international = [[International Freedom Alliance]] | european = [[European Alliance for Freedom]] | europarl = [[Europe of Nations and Freedom]] | colours = {{Color box|#AE1C28|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|#FFFFFF|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|#21468B|border=darkgray}} [[Red]], [[white]], [[blue]]
([[Flag of the Netherlands|Dutch tricolour]]) | seats1_title = [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|20|150|hex={{Party for Freedom/meta/color}}}} | seats2_title = [[Senate (Netherlands)|Senate]] | seats2 = {{Composition bar|9|75|hex={{Party for Freedom/meta/color}}}} | seats3_title = [[States-Provincial]] | seats3 = {{Composition bar|66|570|hex={{Party for Freedom/meta/color}}}} | seats4_title = [[European Parliament]] | seats4 = {{Composition bar|4|26|hex={{Party for Freedom/meta/color}}}} | website = {{URL|https://www.pvv.nl/}} | country = Netherlands }} The '''Party for Freedom''' ({{lang-nl|Partij voor de Vrijheid}}, '''PVV''') is a Dutch [[Nationalism|nationalist]] and [[Right-wing populism|right-wing populist]] [[list of political parties in the Netherlands|political party]] in the [[Netherlands]]. Founded in 2006 as the successor to [[Geert Wilders]]' one-man party in the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]], it won nine seats in the [[Dutch general election, 2006|2006 general election]] making it the fifth-largest party in parliament. In the [[Dutch general election, 2010|2010 general election]] it won 24 seats, making it the third-largest party. At that time the PVV agreed to support the [[minority government]] led by [[Prime Minister of the Netherlands|Prime Minister]] [[Mark Rutte]] without having ministers in the [[First Rutte cabinet|cabinet]]. However the PVV withdrew its support in April 2012 due to differences over budget cuts at the Catshuis.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423035742/http://www.euronews.com/newswires/1490908-dutch-elections-loom-as-budget-talks-collapse/|archivedate=23 April 2012|title=Dutch elections loom as budget talks collapse|url=http://www.euronews.com/newswires/1490908-dutch-elections-loom-as-budget-talks-collapse/|publisher=''[[Euronews]]''|accessdate=22 April 2012}} It came third in the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (Netherlands)|2014 European Parliament election]], winning four out of 26 seats.{{cite web|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/652748-cda-5-zetels-d66-en-pvv-4.html|title=Meeste stemmen D66, CDA grootst|work=nos.nl}}{{cite web |date=25 May 2014 |title=CDA met vijf zetels grootste partij |url=http://www.rtlnieuws.nl/nieuws/special/cda-met-vijf-zetels-grootste-partij |website=RTL Nieuws |accessdate=26 May 2014 |language=Dutch }} In the 2017 election, the Party for Freedom won 20 seats, making it the second-largest party in [[Dutch Parliament|Parliament]]. The PVV calls for items like [[administrative detention]] and a strong [[Cultural assimilation|assimilationist]] stance on the [[Integration law for immigrants to the Netherlands|integration]] of immigrants into Dutch society, differing from the established [[Centre-right politics|centre-right]] parties in the Netherlands (like the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]], VVD). The PVV has also proposed banning the [[Quran]] and shutting down all [[mosque]]s in the Netherlands. In addition, the party is consistently [[Euroscepticism|Eurosceptic]]{{Cite book |first=José M. |last=Magone |title=Comparative European Politics: An Introduction |publisher=Routledge |year=2011 |page=17| url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=g73UtvxJsFcC }} }}{{Citation |first1=Daniele |last1=Albertazzi |first2=Duncan |last2=McDonnell |title=Twenty-first century populism: The spectre of Western European democracy |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |year=2008 |page=164 |url={{Google books |plainurl=yes |id=tCGIAAAAMAAJ }} }} and since early July 2012, according to the platform it presented prior to elections in September, it strongly advocates withdrawal from the [[European Union|EU]].{{cite web|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/390859-pvv-nederland-moet-uit-eu.html |title=PVV: Nederland moet uit EU. (The Netherlands should get out of the EU) |publisher=Nos.nl |date=23 April 2010 |accessdate=15 January 2014}} Party for Freedom is an association with Geert Wilders as its sole member. The party is ineligible for Dutch government funding and relies on donations.{{cite web|last=Bolopion |first=Philippe |url=http://www.politico.eu/article/geert-wilders-far-right-party-suffers-donation-downturn/ |title=Geert Wilders' far-right party suffers donation downturn |publisher=Politico.eu |date=8 March 2017|accessdate=17 March 2017}} ==History== === 2004–2005 === The party's history began with Geert Wilders' departure from the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy|VVD]] in September 2004. Wilders could not accept the VVD's positive stance towards [[Accession of Turkey to the European Union|Turkey's possible accession to the European Union]], and left the party disgruntled.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Although the VVD expected Wilders to return his parliamentary seat to the party, he refused, and continued to sit in parliament as a one-man party, ''Groep Wilders'' (Wilders Group).{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In June 2005, Wilders was one of the leaders in the campaign against the [[Treaty establishing a Constitution for Europe|European Constitution]], which was rejected by Dutch voters by 62%.{{cite news|title=Dutch say 'No' to EU constitution|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4601439.stm| publisher= BBC News |date=2 June 2005|accessdate=4 April 2009}} === 2006–2010 === [[File:Slotdebat verkiezingen (final debate elections) 2006.jpg|thumb|[[Geert Wilders]] (left) with other politicians at the final television debate before the [[Dutch general election, 2006]]]] On 22 February 2006, the Party for Freedom was registered with the Electoral Council. [[Bart Jan Spruyt]], director of the [[conservatism|conservative]] [[Edmund Burke Foundation]], joined Wilders in January 2006 in order to formulate a party programme and to train its prospective representatives for the forthcoming national election (then still scheduled for 2007).{{cite news|title=Spruyt sluit zich aan bij Geert Wilders|language=Dutch|url=http://www.elsevier.nl/web/1062338/Nieuws/Politiek/Spruyt-sluit-zich-aan-bij-Geert-Wilders.htm|publisher=[[Elsevier (magazine)|Elsevier]]|date=4 January 2006|accessdate=4 April 2009}} Spruyt left the party in the summer of 2006 after it proved unable to build broad conservative backing, and people like [[Joost Eerdmans]] and [[Marco Pastors]] proved unwilling to join.{{cite news|title=Historische kans voorbij |language=Dutch |url=http://www.refdag.nl/artikel/1271047 |publisher=[[Reformatorisch Dagblad]] |date=17 August 2006 |first=Addy |last=de Jong |accessdate=4 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080526150442/http://www.refdag.nl/artikel/1271047 |archivedate=26 May 2008 }} After the [[Dutch general election, 2006|2006 elections]], Spruyt said he was not surprised that the Party for Freedom had gained seats but maintained that, if the Party for Freedom had sought cooperation with Eerdmans and Pastors, it would have won more, even enough to bring about a [[Christian Democratic Appeal|CDA]]-[[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy|VVD]] [[Dutch general election, 2006#Possible coalitions|majority]] government.{{cite news|title=Spruyt: Negeren van Wilders onverstandig|language=Dutch|url=http://www.refdag.nl/artikel/1282578/Spruyt%3A+Negeren+van+Wilders+onverstandig.html|publisher=[[Reformatorisch Dagblad]]|date=23 November 2006|first=Jacob|last=Hoekman|accessdate=4 April 2009}} Later, Spruyt commented that the PVV had a 'natural tendency' toward fascism.{{cite news|title=Weimar in aanbouw (deel 1)|language=Dutch|url=http://bartjanspruyt.blogspot.com/2007/01/weimar-in-aanbouw-deel-1.html|publisher=The weblog of Bart J. Spruyt|first=Bart|last=Spruyt|date=1 January 2007|accessdate=4 April 2009}} He later qualified the statement, though he didn't withdraw it. Former PVV candidate [[Lucas Hartong]] called Spruyt's claims 'a cheap insinuation'.{{cite news|title=Het is me wat!| url=http://www.hetvrijevolk.com/?pagina=2295&titel=Het_is_me_wat|first=Lucas|last=Hartong|date=2 January 2007|accessdate=4 April 2009|language=Dutch|publisher=[[Het Vrije Volk]]}} In an ''[[HP/De Tijd]]'' profile dated December 2006, the party was described as a [[cult]], with an extremely distrustful Wilders only accepting fellow candidates completely loyal to him, and compared the PVV to the [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Socialist Party]] led by [[Jan Marijnissen]] but without reaching that degree of organisational perfection.{{Cite journal|title=Haagse Sekte| language=Dutch| author=van der Horst, Alain |author2=Munk, Kirsten |author3=Niemoller, Joost|publisher=[[HP/De Tijd]]|date=1 December 2006}} On 10 January 2007, the PVV announced it would not field candidates at the forthcoming Provincial elections. This meant it would be unrepresented in the [[Senate (Netherlands)|Senate]].{{cite news|title=Partij Wilders doet niet mee aan Statenverkiezingen|url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/binnenland/article386300.ece/Partij_Wilders_doet_niet_mee_aan_Statenverkiezingen|publisher=[[Volkskrant]]|date=10 January 2007|language=Dutch|accessdate=4 April 2009|work=[[Algemeen Nederlands Persbureau|ANP]]}} On 13 January 2007, ''[[NRC Handelsblad]]'' reported that a PVV intern had solicited for signatures on the website forums ''Dutch Disease Report'' and ''Polinco'', the latter a forum described as far-right by various organisations, among them the Dutch Complaints Bureau for Discrimination on the Internet.{{cite web|url=http://www.meldpunt.nl/dl/mdi-jaarverslag-2003.pdf|title=Meldpunt Discriminatie Internet|language=Dutch|publisher=Magenta Foundation|date=1 March 2004|accessdate=4 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20040808184259/http://www.meldpunt.nl/dl/mdi-jaarverslag-2003.pdf|archivedate=8 August 2004}} Any party participating in this election was required to collect at least 30 signatures from supporters in each of the 19 electoral districts; of the 1500 signatures the PVV received, the [[Antifaschistische Aktion|Dutch Antifascist]] group identified 34 known far-right supporters. In a response, Wilders said he regretted that far-right sympathisers had provided signatures, denied any personal responsibility for them and reasserted his dislike of far-right parties like [[National Front (France)|National Front]] of France and [[Vlaams Belang|Flemish Interest]].{{Cite news|publisher=[[NRC Handelsblad]]| language=Dutch| date=13 January 2007|accessdate=4 April 2009|title=PVV riep steun van extreem-rechts in| url= http://www.nrc.nl/binnenland/article598698.ece/PVV_riep_steun_van_extreem-rechts_in| first=Joep| last=Dohmen}}{{Cite news|publisher=[[Trouw]]|language=Dutch|date=13 January 2007| title=Wilders ontkent oproep tot steun extreem rechts|url=http://www.trouw.nl/laatstenieuws/laatstenieuws/article598962.ece/Wilders_ontkent_oproep_tot_steun_extreem_rechts}}{{Cite news|publisher=[[de Volkskrant]]| date=15 January 2007|title=Extreem-rechtse steun verdriet Wilders|url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/binnenland/article387621.ece/Extreem-rechtse_steun_verdriet_Wilders|accessdate=5 April 2009| language= Dutch}} Noted writer and columnist [[Leon de Winter]] later declared the affair to be the result of a campaign of [[demonization|demonisation]] against Geert Wilders led by ''NRC Handelsblad'' and ''[[de Volkskrant]]'' newspapers, as well as the broadcaster [[Omroepvereniging VARA|VARA]].{{Cite news| url= http://www.elsevier.nl/opinie/weblog/asp/artnr/134700/weblogid/4/index.html|title=De demonisering van Geert Wilders|language=Dutch|publisher=[[Elsevier]]|date=15 January 2007|accessdate=4 April 2009| first=Leon| last=de Winter}} [[File:Wilders.jpg|thumb|left|[[Geert Wilders]] in 2007]] Former [[trade union]] leader and prominent [[Christian Democratic Appeal|Christian Democrat]] Doekle Terpstra proposed an initiative against Geert Wilders and the PVV on 30 November 2007, in the newspaper ''[[Trouw]]''.{{cite news|first=Doekle|last=Terpstra|title=’Nee’ tegen kwade boodschap Wilders| language=Dutch| url=http://www.trouw.nl/opinie/podium/article1518091.ece|publisher=[[Trouw]]|date=30 November 2007| accessdate=4 April 2009}} Terpstra sees Wilders as promoting intolerance, and discrimination against Muslims. He is supported in his cause by the large Dutch trade unions and refugee organisations. Politicians and the public are divided on Terpstra's initiative.{{cite news|title=Dutch show mixed reactions to anti-Muslim party |url=http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/071204-freedom-party-mc |publisher=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]] |date=4 December 2007 |accessdate=4 April 2009 |first=Hans |last=Andringa |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018231807/http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/071204-freedom-party-mc |archivedate=18 October 2008 }} The newspaper ''[[De Pers]]'' reported the next day that much of Terpstra's support did not actualise.{{cite news|title=Tekort aan redelijke positivo's|url=http://www.depers.nl/binnenland/135616/Tekort-aan-redelijke-positivos.html|language=Dutch|publisher=[[De Pers]]|date=5 December 2007|accessdate=4 April 2009|first=Kustaw|last=Bessems}} In 2008, the Friends of the Party of Freedom commissioned a producer, who acted under the name of "Scarlet Pimpernel Productions", a pseudonym adopted out of fear of reprisal,{{cite news|url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/binnenland/article524165.ece/Rapper_wil_25.000_euro_van_Wilders|title=Rapper wil 25.000 euro van Wilders|publisher=[[de Volkskrant]]|date=7 April 2008|accessdate=8 April 2008|work=[[Algemeen Nederlands Persbureau]]|language=Dutch}} to produce ''[[Fitna (film)|Fitna]]'' ({{lang-ar|فِتْنَةٌ}}), a [[short film]] by Geert Wilders. Approximately 17 minutes in length, it shows selected excerpts from [[Surah|Suras]] of the [[Quran|Qur'an]], interspersed with media clips and newspaper cuttings showing or describing acts of violence or hatred by Muslims. The film attempts to demonstrate that the Qur'an motivates its followers to hate all who violate Islamic teachings. Consequently, the film argues that Islam encourages acts of terrorism, [[antisemitism]], [[violence against women]] and homosexuals, and Islamic [[universalism]]. A large part of the film deals with [[Islam in the Netherlands|the influence of Islam on the Netherlands]]. The film's title, the Arabic word "[[fitna (word)|fitna]]", means either "disagreement and division among people" or a "test of faith in times of trial".{{cite news|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/detaylar.do?load=detay&link=137624|title=Hold your breath: ‘Fitna' spreading seeds of hatred|date=29 March 2008|accessdate=1 April 2008|work=[[Today's Zaman]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080402234115/http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/detaylar.do?load=detay&link=137624|archivedate=2 April 2008|df=dmy-all}} Wilders described the film as "a call to shake off the creeping tyranny of [[Islamization|Islamisation]]".{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,324406,00.html|title=Iran Warns Netherlands Not to Air Controversial 'Anti-Muslim' Film|publisher=Fox News|first=Michael|last=Park|date=21 January 2008|accessdate=8 March 2008}} Polling by [[Maurice de Hond]] published in March 2009 indicated that the PVV was the most popular parliamentary party. The polls predicted that the party would take 21 per cent of the national vote, giving it 32 out of 150 seats in the Dutch parliament. If the polling results were to be replicated at a genuine election, Wilders would be a major power broker and could become Prime Minister.{{Cite news|url=http://www.radionetherlands.nl/news/zijlijn/6235703/Geert-Wilders-Freedom-Party-rises-to-32-seats |title=Geert Wilders' Freedom Party rises to 32 seats |date=29 March 2009 |accessdate=29 March 2009 |publisher=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402002907/http://www.radionetherlands.nl/news/zijlijn/6235703/Geert-Wilders-Freedom-Party-rises-to-32-seats |archivedate=2 April 2009 }}{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/netherlands/4933687/Geert-Wilders-leads-Dutch-polls.html|title=Geert Wilders leads Dutch polls |first=Bruno|last=Waterfield|date=3 March 2009|accessdate=4 April 2009|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK }}{{Cite news|url=http://www.nisnews.nl/public/030309_1.htm|title=Wilders Now a Celebrity in US and Prime Minister in Poll|publisher=NIS News Bulletin|date=3 March 2009|accessdate=4 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090722014951/http://www.nisnews.nl/public/030309_1.htm|archivedate=22 July 2009|df=dmy-all}} However, De Hond's results were not uncontroversial, as they were based on a panel of people who have signed up for the election poll on the Internet and thus were not a [[random sample]]. According to Joop van Holsteyn, professor of election research, therefore, De Hond's polls were not [[Face validity|representative]] of the population.{{cite web|url=http://www.nrc.nl/opinie/article2168483.ece/De_peiling_van_Maurice_de_Hond_deugt_niet|title=De peiling van Maurice de Hond deugt niet; De waarde van een peiling staat of valt met een representatieve steekproef|publisher=NRC Handelsblad|author=Joop van Holsteyn}} Other Dutch polls (Politieke Barometer and TNS NIPO) have shown contrasting results, with the PVV often getting less support, though still remaining very popular. On 15 May 2009, the PVV asked Balkenende to support the foundation of a [[Greater Netherlands]] actively.{{cite web|url=http://www.pvv.nl/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1975&Itemid=1|title=Partij Voor de Vrijheid|work=pvv.nl}}{{third-party-inline|date=January 2012}} By February 2010, the PVV had once more become the most popular party, according to a poll by Maurice de Hond which said it would win 27–32 parliameary seats in the next election, up two from the previous poll in early January.{{cite web|url=http://www.angus-reid.com/polls/view/35028/dutch_party_for_freedom_recovers_top_rank/ |title=Dutch Party for Freedom Recovers Top Rank |publisher=Angus-reid.com |accessdate=18 June 2010}}{{cite web| url= http://digitalehofstad.wordpress.com/2010/01/31/2e-kamerverkiezingen-2010-%E2%80%93-peilingen-31-01-2010-maurice-de-hond-pvv-de-grootste/ |title=2e Kamerverkiezingen 2010 – Peilingen 31.01.2010 Maurice de Hond PVV de Grootste |publisher=Digitalehofstad.wordpress.com |date=31 January 2010 |accessdate=18 June 2010}} On 3 March 2010, elections for the local councils were held in the municipalities of the Netherlands. The PVV only contested these in [[The Hague]] and [[Almere]], because of a shortage of good candidates. MP Raymond de Roon headed the campaign in his home town of Almere. Fellow MP Sietse Fritsma was appointed head of the local election campaign in The Hague. Both men would continue to serve as MPs as well as local councillors after their election.{{cite web|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2009/12/pvv_picks_second_mp_for_local.php |title=PVV picks second MP for local elections |publisher=Dutchnews.nl |date=21 December 2009 |accessdate=18 June 2010}} The PVV made big gains, suggesting that the party and Wilders might dominate the political scene in the run-up to the parliamentary elections scheduled on 9 June 2010. The PVV won in Almere and came second to the Labour Party in The Hague. In Almere, the PVV won 21 percent of the vote to Labour's 18 percent, preliminary results showed. In The Hague, the PVV had 8 seats – second to Labour with 10 seats. The local elections were the first test of public opinion since the collapse of the 4th Balkenende cabinet in February 2010. The municipal elections were overshadowed by the fall of the cabinet and the forthcoming parliamentary elections.{{cite web|url=http://www.nrc.nl/international/Features/article2497139.ece/Local_elections_overshadowed_by_national_politics |title=Local elections overshadowed by national politics |publisher=Nrc.nl |accessdate=18 June 2010}} On 8 March 2010, Wilders announced he would take a seat on The Hague city council, after it became clear that he had won 13,000 preference votes. Earlier he had said he would not do so.{{cite web|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2010/03/wilders_to_take_council_seat_i.php |title=Wilders to take council seat in the Hague |publisher=Dutchnews.nl |date=8 March 2010 |accessdate=18 June 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/dutch-anti-Islam-MP-Wilders-wins-council-seat |title=Anti-Islam MP Geert Wilders has announced he will take up a seat on the local council of the city of The Hague |publisher=Rnw.nl |date=8 March 2010 |accessdate=18 June 2010}} One week after these local elections, the PVV called for an inquiry into the elections in The Hague, since a YouTube clip allegedly showed irregularities, including more than one person entering polling booths at the same time and a voter not putting the ballot paper into the box. These calls were rejected. The Hague council said the municipal elections had gone well and that any complaint should anyway have been lodged immediately after the results were announced. In [[Rotterdam]], a full recount was held after a protest by [[Livable Rotterdam|Leefbaar Rotterdam]], a local party with a programme broadly similar to that of the PVV.{{cite web|url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/calls-local-poll-recount-hague |title=Calls for local poll recount in The Hague |publisher=Rnw.nl |date=10 March 2010 |accessdate=18 June 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/rotterdam-investigate-proxy-voting |title=Rotterdam to investigate proxy voting |publisher=Rnw.nl |date=10 March 2010 |accessdate=18 June 2010}} On 18 March 2010, the PVV gave up trying to form a governing coalition in Almere. In a press release, the party said most of the other parties had refused to give ground to PVV demands on what it describes as ''"essential issues"''. These include what the party calls ‘city commandos’: street patrols to keep order in the face of inadequate proper law enforcement. Other obstacles were the PVV's demands for reduced taxes for Almere residents and its fight against what the party sees as ''"the increasing influence of Islam in Dutch society"''. The PVV complained that it was forced to stay in the opposition through the manoeuvring of the political elite.{{cite web|url=http://www.expatica.com/nl/news/dutch-rss-news/wilders-pvv-party-kept-in-almere-opposition_31769.html |title=Wilders' PVV party 'kept in Almere opposition' |publisher=Expatica.com |accessdate=18 June 2010}} === 2010–2012 === [[File:2010-presentatie-regeerakkoord2.jpg|thumb|[[Maxime Verhagen]] (left) and [[Mark Rutte]] (center) are presenting the coalition agreement with support of the PVV of [[Geert Wilders]] (right) in 2010]] [[File:Pvv.png|thumb|Distribution of the people that voted for the Party for Freedom in 2010]] In the parliamentary elections of 9 June 2010, the PVV went from 9 to 24 seats (of 150), winning over 15% of the votes, making the PVV the third largest party in parliament.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} By July 2010, the PVV again became the biggest party in the polls after the [[Dutch general election, 2010|parliamentary elections]], following difficulties in forming a new coalition and the PVV technically being excluded from the coalition talks because the CDA showed reluctance to cooperate with the PVV. According to the polls, the PVV would get 35 seats in a new election, which is a record high number.{{cite web|url=http://www.nu.nl/politiek/2295043/pvv-historisch-hoog-in-peiling.html |title=PVV historisch hoog in peiling |publisher=www.nu.nl |date=18 July 2010 |accessdate=20 July 2010}} In August 2010, during the difficult cabinet formation following the elections, the PVV emerged as a prominent player in a proposal for a new minority government in the Netherlands. While the party would not gain a ministerial appointment, the PVV would tolerate a centre-right minority government coalition: a proposed deal that would make the party one of the most influential forces. Led by [[Ivo Opstelten]], a former mayor of Rotterdam who was appointed mediator for the next stage of negotiations, the forming of a government of VVD and [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] (CDA) with support of the PVV was negotiated; the resulting coalition agreement "included elements it pushed for, such as a [[Islamic dress in Europe#Netherlands|burqa ban]]," though the ban was never put in place.{{cite news| title= Dutch government collapses after far right pulls plug| url= http://www.cnn.com/2012/04/23/world/europe/netherlands-politics/ |date= 23 April 2012| publisher= CNN| quote= The Party for Freedom did not get control of any government ministries, but the coalition agreement included elements it pushed for, such as a burqa ban. No ban has been put in place.| accessdate=23 April 2012}} The VVD and CDA would have to rely on the PVV to get important legislation through. With this deal the Netherlands would follow the "Danish model", since in Denmark the anti-immigration [[Danish People's Party]] also stayed out of government but supported a minority center-right [[Venstre (Denmark)|Liberal]]-[[Conservative People's Party (Denmark)|Conservative]] government.{{cite news|last=Castle |first=Stephen |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/06/world/europe/06dutch.html |title=Outspoken Dutch Politician Makes Inroads |location=Netherlands |publisher= The New York Times |date=5 August 2010 |accessdate=18 December 2011}} The very fact of the participation of the PVV in these coalition negotiations has caused fierce discussions in political circles{{which|date=December 2017}} and was considered{{by whom|date=December 2017}} very unlikely until recently.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} After the elections, CDA parliamentary fraction president Maxime Verhagen first had stated that as a matter of principle he refused to negotiate with VVD and PVV about a centre-right government, saying that the PVV represented views that could not be reconciled with Dutch law. These objections on principle disappeared in five weeks and Verhagen turned out to be willing to negotiate over a cabinet whose fate would (also) lie in the hands of Wilders.{{cite web|url=http://www.trouw.nl/opinie/commentaar/article3153262.ece/Vooral_het_CDA_heeft_niets_te_zoeken_in_zo_rsquo_n__rsquo_bijzonder_rsquo__kabinet_.html |title=Vooral het CDA heeft niets te zoeken in zo’n ’bijzonder’ kabinet |publisher=Trouw.nl |language=Dutch| accessdate=18 December 2011}} On 20 March 2012, [[Hero Brinkman]] quit the party, citing a lack of democratic structure within the PVV among other things; qualifying this with a statement of continued support for the minority [[First Rutte cabinet|Rutte cabinet]].{{cite web|title=Hero Brinkman quits the PVV, opposition call for new elections| url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2012/03/hero_brinkman_quits_the_pvv_op.php| publisher=''DutchNews.nl''|accessdate=8 April 2012}} Two days later, three members of the [[States of North Holland]] representing the PVV followed his example.{{cite web| url= http://article.wn.com/view/WNAT0cc025902c4813c68046c95b3a128b8b/| title= Drie Statenleden PVV Noord-Holland mee met Brinkman| language=Dutch|accessdate=8 April 2012| publisher= World News Network | work= wn.com}} In July 2012, [[Marcial Hernandez]] and [[Wim Kortenoeven]] quit the PVV, both citing what they considered to be Wilders' autocratic leadership of the party.{{cite web|last=Chesal|first=Robert|title=Wilders gives Dutch politics a roller-coaster ride|url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/wilders-gives-dutch-politics-a-roller-coaster-ride|publisher=''[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]]''|accessdate=16 July 2012}} === 2012–2017 === [[File:Congresso federale straordinario - Torino, 15 dicembre 2013 29.JPG|thumb|[[Geert Wilders]] speaking at a [[Lega Nord]] event in 2013]] In the [[Dutch general election, 2012|parliamentary elections of 12 September 2012]], the PVV went from 24 to 15 seats (of 150), winning 10% of the vote.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In October 2013, the party expelled [[Louis Bontes]], but he kept his seat in parliament.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In March 2014, [[Roland van Vliet]] and [[Joram van Klaveren]] left the party and also kept their seats in parliament.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} In the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (Netherlands)|European Parliament election]] on 22 May 2014, the party kept its four seats in the [[European Parliament]].{{cite web |date=26 May 2014 |title=Dit zijn de Nederlandse leden van het Europees parlement |url=http://www.rtlnieuws.nl/nieuws/special/dit-zijn-de-nederlandse-leden-van-het-europees-parlement |website=RTL Nieuws |accessdate=26 May 2014 |language=Dutch }} MEP [[Hans Jansen]] died on 5 May 2015 and was replaced by [[Auke Zijlstra]] on 1 September 2015."[https://www.parlement.com/id/vjvuh0bgrcmd/nieuws/auke_zijlstra_pvv_bevestigt_toetreding Auke Zijlstra (PVV) bevestigt toetreding tot Europees Parlement]" (in Dutch), ''Parlement & Politiek'', 2015. Retrieved 19 March 2017. On 16 June 2015, the Party for Freedom and other right-wing nationalist parties in the European Parliament formed the [[Political groups of the European Parliament|political group]] [[Europe of Nations and Freedom]]."[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-33147247 France's Le Pen announces far-right bloc of anti-EU MEPs]", ''[[BBC News]]'', 2015. Retrieved 19 March 2017.Eric Maurice, "[https://euobserver.com/political/129140 Le Pen becomes group leader in EU parliament]", ''[[EUobserver]]'', 2015. Retrieved 19 March 2017. [[Marcel de Graaff]] of the PVV and [[Marine Le Pen]] of the [[National Front (France)|National Front]] became the first co-presidents of this group. === 2017–present === [[File:Geert Wilders tijdens een politieke campagne in Spijkenisse.jpg|thumb|[[Geert Wilders]] during the campaign of the [[Dutch general election, 2017|2017 general election]]]] For the [[Dutch general election, 2017|2017 Dutch general election]], the Party for Freedom had an [[election platform]] of a single page."[http://pubnpp.eldoc.ub.rug.nl/FILES/root/verkiezingsprogramma/TK/pvv2017con/PVV2017-2021con.pdf Concept-verkiezingsprogramma PVV 2017-2021]" (in Dutch), [[University of Groningen]]. Retrieved 19 March 2017. Before the election, all major parties said they would not form a government coalition with the PVV.{{cite news|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2017/01/vvd-leader-mark-rutte-says-zero-chance-of-coalition-with-geert-wilders|title=VVD leader Mark Rutte says 'zero' chance of coalition with Geert Wilders|publisher=DutchNews.nl|date=16 January 2017}} A typical House of Representatives has a large number of parties represented, since it takes as little as 0.67 percent of the vote to get a seat. With such a fragmented vote, the PVV would have needed the support of other parties in order to make Wilders prime minister, even if it won the most seats in the House of Representatives. Wilders hinted that a "revolution" would occur if the PVV won the most seats and was still locked out of power.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/dutch-election-far-right-could-win-not-rule-country-known-liberal/|title=Dutch election: How the far Right could win but not rule in a country known for its liberal values|author1=Ashley Kirk|author2=Patrick Scott|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=17 March 2017}} The party won 20 seats (of 150) according to the preliminary results, which is 5 seats more than in the previous [[Dutch general election, 2012|election in 2012]] and made it the second-largest party in Parliament."[http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/27813134/__VVD_de_grootste__.html VVD de grootste, zwaar verlies PvdA]" (in Dutch), ''[[De Telegraaf]]'', 2017. Retrieved 17 March 2017. ==Ideology== {{Updatesection|date=October 2016}} The Party for Freedom combines conservative, liberal, right and left standpoints in a populistic programme.[http://www.parlement.com/9291000/modulesf/g45eq8f7 Partijen in de Eerste en Tweede Kamer - PVV], Parlement.com. On certain themes like healthcare, social services and elderly care the PVV can be seen as left and social, though selective.[https://nrc.nl/nieuws/2017/03/12/de-pvv-is-best-sociaal-maar-wel-selectief-7328509-a1549996 De PVV is best sociaal, maar wel selectief], ''NRC Handelsblad'', 12 maart 2017 (ism. Parlementair Documentatiecentrum) Regarding immigration and culture the party is nationalistic. It believes that the [[Judeo-Christian]] and [[humanism|humanist]] traditions should be taken as the dominant culture in the Netherlands, and that immigrants should adapt accordingly. The party wants a halt to immigration especially from non-Western countries. It is hostile towards the EU, is against future [[Enlargement of the European Union|EU enlargement]] to Muslim-majority countries like Turkey and opposes a dominant presence of Islam in the Netherlands.{{cite web|url=http://www.pvv-europa.nl/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4&Itemid=2|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090410003337/http://pvv-europa.nl/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4&Itemid=2|dead-url=yes|archive-date=10 April 2009|title=Standpunten|language=Dutch|work=Voor Nederland in Europa|publisher=Party for Freedom|date=1 April 2009|accessdate=7 April 2009|df=dmy-all}} More specifically, the party has called for a banning the [[Quran]], and shutting down all mosques in the Netherlands.{{cite news|title=Dutch party wants to outlaw mosques, Islamic schools, Koran|url=http://www.politico.eu/article/far-right-dutch-politician-backs-mosques-koran-ban-islamic-schools/|publisher=[[Politico]]}}{{cite news|title=Dutch Far-right Leader Seeks Ban on Quran, Mosques|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/netherlands-wilders-mosque-quran-ban/3482009.html}}{{cite news|title=The Netherlands' most popular party wants to ban all mosques|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/netherlands-pvv-leader-geert-wilders-koran-islam-mosque-ban-holland-dutch-pm-favourite-a7214356.html}} The party is also opposed to [[dual citizenship]] (see below). The Parliamentary Documentation Center (Parlementair Documentatie Centrum) of the [[Leiden University]] characterises the PVV as "[[populism|populist]], with both [[conservatism|conservative]], [[liberalism|liberal]], [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] and [[left-wing politics|left-wing]] positions".[http://www.parlement.com/9291000/modulesf/g45eq8f7 Partijen in de Eerste en Tweede Kamer - PVV], Parlement.com [[File:Pol-landschap-2012.png|thumb|250px|On [[André Krouwel]]'s map of the Dutch political spectrum in 2012, the Party for Freedom is [[Conservatism|conservative]] on the socio-cultural axis, and [[Centrism|centrist]] on the socio-economic axis.]] In December 2008, the eighth study "Monitor Racism and Extremism",{{Citation |url=http://www.annefrank.org/upload/Downloads/Monitor2008-8.pdf |first1=Jaap |last1=Van Donselaar |first2=Peter R. |last2=Rodrigues |title=Monitor Racisme & Extremisme |publisher=Pallas Publications |year=2008 |language=Dutch}} conducted by the [[Anne Frank Foundation]] and the [[Leiden University]], has found that the Party for Freedom can be considered [[Far-right politics|extreme right-wing]], although "with ifs and buts". Economically they are viewed as a left-wing party. Peter Rodrigues and Jaap van Donselaar, who have academically guided the study, explain this classification with the [[Islamophobia]], [[nationalism]], and "sharp aversion to the strange", subsumed as [[racism]], which they have observed within the party.{{Citation |url=http://www.nieuws.leidenuniv.nl/nieuwsarchief/monitor-racisme-en-extremisme.html |title=Monitor Racisme en Extremisme |publisher=University of Leiden |date=10 December 2008 |language=Dutch |accessdate=24 August 2011}}{{Citation |url=http://www.nu.nl/algemeen/1880292/pvv-volgens-onderzoekers-extreemrechts.html |title=PVV volgens onderzoekers extreemrechts |publisher=NU.nl |date=10 December 2008|language=Dutch |accessdate=24 August 2011}} In January 2010, the report ''Polarisatie en radicalisering in Nederland''{{Citation |last=Moors |first=Hans|title=Polarisatie en radicalisering in Nederland. Een verkenning van de stand van zaken in 2009 |publisher=IVA beleidsonderzoek en advies |year=2009 |language=Dutch |url=http://www.rijksoverheid.nl/bestanden/documenten-en-publicaties/kamerstukken/2010/01/27/polarisatie-en-radicalisering-in-nederland-een-verkenning-van-de-stand-van-zaken-in-2009/verkenningpr-definitieveversie16-12.pdf|display-authors=etal}} (transl. "Polarisation and radicalisation in the Netherlands") by political researchers Moors, Lenke Balogh, Van Donselaar and De Graaff from the [[Tilburg University]] research group IVA{{cite web |url=http://www.lokaalcentraal.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Polarisering-radicalisering-in-NL.pdf |first1=Hans |last1=Moors |first2=Lenke |last2=Balogh |first3=Jaap |last3=van Donselaar |first4=Bob |last4=de Graaff |title=Polarisatie en radicalisering in Nederland: Een verkenning van de stand van zaken in 2009 |publisher=IVA |year=2009 |accessdate=6 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140316195636/http://www.lokaalcentraal.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Polarisering-radicalisering-in-NL.pdf |archivedate=16 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }} stated that the PVV was not an extreme right-wing party, but contained some radical right-wing elements. The study claims that the PVV holds [[Xenophobia|xenophobic]] ideas, but not antisemitic ideas – the PVV describes its culture as [[Judeo-Christian|Jewish-Christian]] humanistic.{{Citation|author1=Hans Moors|author2=Lenke Balogh|author3=Jaap van Donselaar|author4=Bob de Graaff|title=Polarisatie en radicalising in Nederland. Een verkenning van de stand van zaken in 2009|year=2009|location=Tilburg|url=http://www.iva.nl/uploads/documents/166.pdf|format=PDF|language=Dutch|page=15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724154546/http://www.iva.nl/uploads/documents/166.pdf|archivedate=24 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} "The PVV statements on [[Islamization|Islamisation]] and non-Western immigrants appear to be discriminatory and the party organisation is authoritarian rather than democratic", said the researchers, who were looking into polarisation and radicalism across the Netherlands. They described the PVV as the "new radical right", a party with a national democratic ideology but without extreme right-wing roots. In particular, the report stated that the party's pro-Israel stance showed that it was not [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]]. It tends however towards a national democratic ideology. Wilders called the report "scandalous"—in particular the link between defending the national interest and the radical right.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} An alleged earlier version of the report, leaked to the Dutch daily newspaper ''[[de Volkskrant]]'' in November 2009, said that Wilders' party is an extreme right-wing grouping and a threat to social cohesion and democracy. The paper claimed at the time the researchers were under pressure to water down the conclusions because of their political sensitivity.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} The Dutch [[Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations|Minister of the Interior and Kingdom Relations]] [[Guusje ter Horst]], (2007–2010), [[Labour Party (Netherlands)|Labour (PvdA)]], who commissioned the research, denied exerting any interference.{{cite web|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2010/01/wilders_party_is_new_radical_r.php |title=Wilders' party is 'new radical right' |publisher=Dutchnews.nl |date=28 January 2010 |accessdate=18 June 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/putting-geert-wilders-political-map |title=Putting Geert Wilders on the political map |publisher=Rnw.nl |accessdate=18 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529054622/http://www.rnw.nl/english/article/putting-geert-wilders-political-map |archivedate=29 May 2010 |df=dmy-all }} In response, Wilders accused her of "playing a dirty game".{{cite web |url=http://extra.volkskrant.nl/opinie/artikel/show/id/5059/WC-eend_adviseert_Guusje_ter_Horst |title=WC-eend adviseert Guusje ter Horst |publisher=Extra.volkskrant.nl |accessdate=18 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202133613/http://extra.volkskrant.nl/opinie/artikel/show/id/5059/WC-eend_adviseert_Guusje_ter_Horst |archivedate=2 February 2010 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.elsevier.nl/web/Nieuws/Politiek/257065/Wilders-Minister-Ter-Horst-speelt-vuil-spelletje.htm |title=Wilders: Minister Ter Horst speelt vuil spelletje |publisher=Elsevier.nl |date=30 January 2010 |accessdate=18 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724152439/http://www.elsevier.nl/web/Nieuws/Politiek/257065/Wilders-Minister-Ter-Horst-speelt-vuil-spelletje.htm |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Some commentators and international scholarly publications have argued that the party is far-right; for example, the ex-prime minister [[Dries van Agt|Van Agt]] regards the party as ultra-right-wing, and [[Bert de Vries]] (CDA) draws comparisons with the small [[Centre Party (Netherlands)|Centre Party]].{{Citation|author1=Hans Moors|author2=Lenke Balogh|author3=Jaap van Donselaar|author4=Bob de Graaff|title=Polarisatie en radicalisering in Nederland. Een verkenning van de stand van zaken in 2009|year=2009|location=Tilburg|url=http://www.iva.nl/uploads/documents/166.pdf|format=PDF|language=Dutch|page=96|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724154546/http://www.iva.nl/uploads/documents/166.pdf|archivedate=24 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} The political scientist Lucardie, on the other hand, considers it necessary to reserve the 'far-right' qualification for [[Nazism|national socialists]] and fascists.A. Lucardie, ‘Rechtsextremisme, populisme of democratisch patriotisme? Opmerkingen over de politieke plaatsbepaling van de Partij voor de Vrijheid en Trots op Nederland’, in: G. Voerman (ed.), Jaarboek 2007, Groningen z.j. I hate Islam,' says Holland's rising political star|last=Traynor|first=Ian|date=17 February 2008|accessdate=15 March 2009|work=The Guardian | location=London}} ==Positions== ===Dual nationality=== In February 2007, PVV parliamentarian Fritsma introduced a motion that would have prohibited any parliamentarian or executive branch politician from having [[dual citizenship]]. The PVV claimed that dual nationals have unclear loyalty. The motion would have made it difficult, if not impossible for [[Labour Party (Netherlands)|Labour]] MPs [[Ahmed Aboutaleb]] and [[Nebahat Albayrak]] to become members of the [[fourth Balkenende cabinet]]. The motion had to be withdrawn, however, after objection from the [[List of Speakers of the House of Representatives (Netherlands)|Speaker]] of the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]], Gerdi Verbeet (Labour Party).{{cite news|title=MPs unimpressed with motion from PVV|url=http://www.expatica.com/nl/news/local_news/mps-unimpressed-with-motion-from-pvv-36615.html|publisher=Expatica|date=16 February 2007|accessdate=4 April 2009}} [[Maastricht University]] law professor [[:nl:Twan Tak|Twan Tak]] has commented on the risk in executive branch officials having dual citizenship.{{cite news|title='Smoren discussie dubbel paspoort schandalig'|url=http://www.elsevier.nl/web/10112390/Nieuws/Politiek/Smoren-discussie-dubbel-paspoort-schandalig.htm|language=Dutch|publisher=[[Elsevier (magazine)|Elsevier]]|date=15 February 2007|accessdate=4 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724152348/http://www.elsevier.nl/web/10112390/Nieuws/Politiek/Smoren-discussie-dubbel-paspoort-schandalig.htm|archivedate=24 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} however the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] as reviewed in 2010 ECtHR jurisprudence has reaffirmed that form of discrimination is a violation of a human right.{{cite web|url=http://hudoc.echr.coe.int/sites/eng/pages/search.aspx?i=001-98428|title=HUDOC Search Page|work=coe.int}} However, in 2007 the PVV planned to call for a vote of no confidence against junior ministers Aboutaleb and Albayrak when the [[fourth Balkenende cabinet|new cabinet]] had its first meeting with the House of Representatives, claiming that their respectively Moroccan and Turkish passports put their loyalties into question.{{cite news|title=Dutch politician doubts Muslim ministers' loyalty|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSL242937120070224|agency=Reuters |date=24 February 2007|accessdate=4 April 2009}} In the event, the motion was only supported by the PVV itself.{{cite news|title=Opposition criticises cabinet in debate|url=http://www.expatica.com/actual/article.asp?subchannel_id=19&story_id=37138|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929103132/http://www.expatica.com/actual/article.asp?subchannel_id=19&story_id=37138|archivedate=29 September 2007|publisher=Expatica|date=1 March 2007|accessdate=4 April 2009}} The issue of dual nationality, however, was not over yet. On 2 March 2007, [[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]] reported that Labour Party MP [[Khadija Arib]], who had been sworn into parliament the day before, was sitting on a commission appointed by the [[Mohammed VI of Morocco|king of Morocco]].{{cite news|title=Dutch MP to serve as advisor to Moroccan king|url=http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/dut070302mc|publisher=[[Radio Netherlands]]|date=2 March 2007|author=el Ayoubi, Mohammed|author2=den Boer, Nicolien|accessdate=5 April 2009}} The PVV said that this commission work endangers Arib's loyalty to the Netherlands, and that she should choose between being a member of the Dutch parliament or the Moroccan commission. Geert Wilders said that Arib's remark on national television that her loyalty lay neither with the Netherlands nor Morocco was shameful.{{cite news|title=Kamer akkoord met Marokkaans advieswerk Arib|language=Dutch|url=http://www.elsevier.nl/web/10115100/Nieuws/Politiek/Kamer-akkoord-met-Marokkaans-advieswerk-Arib.htm|publisher=[[Elsevier (magazine)|Elsevier]]|date=8 March 2007|accessdate=5 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724152355/http://www.elsevier.nl/web/10115100/Nieuws/Politiek/Kamer-akkoord-met-Marokkaans-advieswerk-Arib.htm|archivedate=24 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} The liberal VVD party similarly remarked that her "double orientation would hurt Dutch integration."{{cite news|title=Kamp: Nevenfunctie Arib schaadt integratie|language=Dutch|url=http://www.refdag.nl/artikel/1294450/Kamp:+Nevenfunctie+Arib+schaadt+integratie.html|publisher=[[Reformatorisch Dagblad]]|work=[[Algemeen Nederlands Persbureau|ANP]]|date=8 March 2007|accessdate=5 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080526215256/http://www.refdag.nl/artikel/1294450/Kamp:+Nevenfunctie+Arib+schaadt+integratie.html|archivedate=26 May 2008|df=dmy-all}} All other parties were appalled by the PVV and VVD's comments.{{cite news|title=Lange dag in de Kamer met veel hatelijkheden|language=Dutch|url=http://www.nrc.nl/binnenland/article1777410.ece/Lange_dag_in_de_Kamer_met_veel_hatelijkheden|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120905102032/http://www.nrc.nl/binnenland/article1777410.ece/Lange_dag_in_de_Kamer_met_veel_hatelijkheden|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 September 2012|publisher=[[NRC Handelsblad]]|first=Derk|last=Stokmans|date=9 March 2007|accessdate=5 April 2009}} Perhaps in the light of the ''Moldova'' ruling, in the first Rutte government in 2010 chaired by the VVD leader, supported by the PVV, [[Marlies Veldhuijzen van Zanten]] became the new State Secretary for Health, Welfare and Sport, having both Dutch and [[Sweden|Swedish]] nationality.{{cite web|url=http://www.elsevier.nl/web/Nieuws/Politiek/278676/Nieuwe-CDAstaatssecretaris-heeft-dubbele-nationaliteit.htm |title=Nieuwe CDA-staatssecretaris heeft dubbele nationaliteit |publisher=Elsevier.nl |accessdate=15 January 2014}} ===Immigration=== The party fielded a controversial motion in the 2007 ''[[prinsjesdag|general deliberations]]'' on the immigration budget, calling for a stop to immigration from Muslim countries. The [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] at first declined to bring the motion forward for debate. Justice Minister [[Ernst Hirsch Ballin]] said it was in violation of the Dutch constitution and international law.{{cite news|title=Minister: Wilders' moslimmotie is onmogelijk|language=Dutch|url=http://www.elsevier.nl/web/10147551/Nieuws/Politiek/Minister-Wilders-moslimmotie-is-onmogelijk.htm|publisher=[[Elsevier (magazine)|Elsevier]]|date=22 November 2007|accessdate=5 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724152402/http://www.elsevier.nl/web/10147551/Nieuws/Politiek/Minister-Wilders-moslimmotie-is-onmogelijk.htm|archivedate=24 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} Another motion by the PVV, against police officers wearing [[veil]]s, did gain a parliamentary majority.{{cite news|title='Agente met hoofddoek absoluut onwenselijk'|language=Dutch|url=http://www.nu.nl/algemeen/1342274/agente-met-hoofddoek-absoluut-onwenselijk.html|publisher=[[NU.nl]]|date=4 December 2007|accessdate=5 April 2009}} In 2012, the PVV party launched a website named ''Reporting Centre on Central and East Europeans'' to receive complaints about Central and East European immigrants in the Netherlands. 'Do you have problems with people from Central and Eastern Europe? Have you lost your job to a Pole, a Bulgarian, a Romanian or another East European? We want to know,' the website states. It displays newspaper headlines such as 'Wouldn't it be better if you went back home?' and 'East Europeans, increasingly criminal'. The European Commission has condemned the website, and EU Justice Commissioner [[Viviane Reding]] declared, "We call on all citizens of the Netherlands not to join in this intolerance. Citizens should instead clearly state on the PVV's website that Europe is a place of freedom.""[http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2012/02/problems_with_poles_report_the.php Problems with Poles? Report them to us, says new PVV website]". DutchNews.nl. 8 February 2012."[https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE8191ML20120210 Dutch allow Wilders' anti-Pole website, EU critical]". ''Reuters.'' 10 February 2012. The website caused a lot of controversy within the [[European Union]]."[http://www.sofiaecho.com/2012/02/16/1767592_controversy-continues-over-wilders-anti-eastern-european-website Sofiaecho.com 16 February 2012]". {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217125414/http://www.sofiaecho.com/2012/02/16/1767592_controversy-continues-over-wilders-anti-eastern-european-website |date=17 February 2012 }} ===Financing political parties=== PVV declared that, since it is against state subsidies, it rejects its own party to be financially supported by the government and believes the "tax payer should not pay for political parties they don't support".{{cite web|url=http://nos.nl/video/407199-zomergesprek-geert-wilders-pvv.html |title=Zomergesprek: Geert Wilders (PVV) - NOS Nieuws |publisher=Nos.nl |accessdate=15 January 2014}} In 2012, the Dutch Parliament discussed tightening the financial rules for political parties, forcing them to become more transparent. The PVV indicated that it would use any means available not to disclose its donors.{{cite web|url=http://www.parool.nl/parool/nl/3587/POLITIEK-BINNENLAND/article/detail/3139689/2012/01/26/PVV-zoekt-mazen-in-wet-over-giften.dhtml |title=PVV zal alles doen om bekendmaking donateurs te vermijden - POLITIEK BINNENLAND - PAROOL |publisher=Parool.nl |accessdate=15 January 2014}} ===Party platform=== {{Update-section|date=December 2017}} {{third-party|section|date=March 2012}} Other policies that Wilders mentions in his party program for the [[Dutch general election, 2010|2010 general election]]:{{cite web|url=http://www.pvv.nl/images/stories/Webversie_VerkiezingsProgrammaPVV.pdf|language=Dutch|title=De agenda van hoop en optimisme|publisher=Party for Freedom}} * Harsh punishment of [[Antisemitism|violence against Jews]] and the [[LGBT]] community, which it claims particularly comes from the Islamic corner (p. 13) * Recording ethnicity for all Dutch citizens. (p. 11) * Prohibition of [[Dhabihah#Islamic slaughtering|halal]] and [[Shechita|kosher slaughter]] (p. 55) (However Wilders has stated that opposition to kosher slaughter was not part of his party's agenda and that support for the ban had been withdrawn){{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/JewishWorld/JewishNews/Article.aspx?id=282105|title=Group calls on Dutch rightists to support ‘shechita’}} * Limitation of [[Coffeeshop (Netherlands)|cannabis coffee shops]] within a radius of no less than 1 [[Kilometre|kilometer]] from schools (p. 11) * Active repatriation of criminals of foreign citizenship and Dutch nationals originating from the [[Netherlands Antilles]] (p. 11) * [[Deportation]] of criminals having foreign nationality or [[multiple citizenship]] back to their country of origin, after a prison sentence (p. 13) * Restrictions on immigrant labour from new EU member states and Islamic countries (p. 15) * Removal of resources from anti-climate change programs, development aid and immigration services (p. 17) * Abolition of the [[Senate (Netherlands)|Senate]] (p. 19) * Shutting down of all Islamic schools (p. 15) * Ban on [[Women in Islam|Islamic "gender apartheid"]] (p. 15) * General Pension (AOW) age must remain 65 (p. 21) * Governmental communication to be exclusively in Dutch or Frisian (p. 35) * Dutch language proficiency and a 10-year Dutch residency and work experience requirement for welfare assistance (p. 15) * Constitutional protection of the dominance of the Judeo-Christian and humanistic culture of the Netherlands (p. 35) * Choosing to defend the essential elements of Dutch culture: freedom of the LGBT community, as well as assured equality of men and women which Islam may challenge (p. 33) * Repeal of anti-smoking legislation in bars (p. 39) * Investment in more nuclear power plants and clean coal plants to reduce dependency on imported oil and because coal is cheaper (p. 47) * Withdrawal from the [[European Union]]. * Return to the [[Dutch guilder|guilder]] (old Dutch currency) and cease use of the [[euro]]. * Abolition of the European Parliament and no cooperation in any EU activity. * Ask the EU to remove the "Dutch" star in the European flag. * Repeal flight tax or [[Carbon tax|carbon dioxide tax]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} * Binding referendum on subjects like the EU and a multicultural society. * No more tax money to "(political) left" organisations.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} * Keeping track of the ethnicity of people who have committed crimes. * Select policemen on "decisiveness". * Binding assimilation contracts for immigrants. * Taxes on the [[Hijab|Islamic headscarf]] and prohibition of the [[Quran|Koran]]. {{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} * Ban on headscarves in any public function. * Support "[[Afrikaners]]", as it is Dutch heritage. * Opposition to Turkey's membership in NATO; support for remaining in NATO. * Halt all support and "propaganda" for Palestine and Palestinians. * No more [[Wind turbine|windmills]] and funding for durability or CO2 reduction; no more "fiscal greening". {{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} == Name and symbols == The name 'Party for Freedom' (''Partij voor de Vrijheid'') is a reference to the [[Freedom Party (Netherlands)|Freedom Party]] (''Partij van de Vrijheid''), a Dutch political party founded in 1946, shortly after [[World War II]]. In 1948, the Freedom Party went on as the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] (''Volkspartij voor Vrijheid en Democratie''), which is the party Wilders split from.{{cite news|title=Groep Wilders wordt Partij voor de Vrijheid|url=http://www.elsevier.nl/nieuws/politiek/artikel/asp/artnr/88062/index.html|language=Dutch|publisher=[[Elsevier (magazine)|Elsevier]]|date=23 February 2006|accessdate=5 April 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930200935/http://www.elsevier.nl/nieuws/politiek/artikel/asp/artnr/88062/index.html|archivedate=30 September 2007}} The party logo consists of the party name and a [[gull]] in red, white, and blue, which are the colors of the [[Flag of the Netherlands|Dutch flag]].Willem Visser, "[http://sargasso.nl/kleur-en-symboliek-nederlandse-politiek/ Kleur en symboliek in de Nederlandse politiek]" (in Dutch), ''Sargasso.nl'', 2017. Retrieved 5 March 2017. The gull symbolises freedom or liberty.Bas Kromhout, "[https://www.historischnieuwsblad.nl/nl/nieuws/10749/Wilders_gebruikt_%5c%e2%80%98besmet%5c%e2%80%99_logo.html Wilders gebruikt 'besmet' logo]" (in Dutch), ''Historisch Nieuwsblad'', 2008. Retrieved 5 March 2017. The gull had also been used as a symbol by the [[National Socialist Movement in the Netherlands]] on propaganda posters and for their youth wing, but Wilders claimed it was not inspired by Nazi usage."[http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/20624246/__Wilders_woedend_na_NSB-vergelijking__.html Wilders woedend over vergelijking met NSB]" (in Dutch), ''[[De Telegraaf]]'', 2008. Retrieved 5 March 2017. == Organisation == In order to register for elections in the Netherlands, a political party needs to be an [[Voluntary association|association]] ({{Lang-nl|vereniging}}), which can be founded by two or more members."[https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/democratie/vraag-en-antwoord/hoe-richt-ik-een-politieke-partij-op Hoe richt ik een politieke partij op?]" (in Dutch), ''[[Government of the Netherlands]]''. Retrieved 4 March 2017."[https://www.notaris.nl/een-vereniging-oprichten Hoe richt ik een vereniging op?]" (in Dutch), ''Notaris.nl''. Retrieved 4 March 2017. The Vereniging Groep Wilders (Association Group Wilders) was founded by the [[natural person]] Geert Wilders and Stichting Groep Wilders ([[Foundation (nonprofit)|Foundation]] Group Wilders), of which Wilders is the only board member.Koen Vossen, "[http://www.montesquieu-instituut.nl/id/vj5eflkxm6yg/een_unieke_partij_de_organisatie_van_de Een unieke partij. De organisatie van de PVV]" (in Dutch), ''Montesquieu Instituut'', 2012. Retrieved 4 March 2017.Paul Lucardie, "[http://dnpp.ub.rug.nl/dnpp/pp/pvv/geschied PVV partijgeschiedenis]" (in Dutch), ''[[University of Groningen]]'', 2013. Retrieved 4 March 2017. The association was later renamed to Partij voor de Vrijheid (Party for Freedom). After the creation of the association, Wilders disabled new member registration, resulting in his remaining the sole member of the party. The party does not organise public [[party conference]]s and does not have local departments, a [[youth wing]], or a [[Think tank|research institute]]. ==Financing== In the Netherlands, a political party needs to have 1,000 members or more to be eligible for government funding, a requirement which the Party for Freedom does not meet with Wilders being the only member."[http://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0033004/2016-01-01 Wet financiering politieke partijen]" (in Dutch), ''[[Government of the Netherlands]]'', 2016. Retrieved 9 March 2017. On several instances the PVV applied for and received European Union funding."[http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2012/09/pvv_wrongly_claims_13000_from.php PVV wrongly claims €13,000 from Brussels for euro report: tv show]", ''DutchNews.nl'', 2012. Financially, the party has been largely relying on donations. The party has not disclosed any of its finances until 2013. According to [[Hero Brinkman]], a former MP for the party, the PVV received most of its finances from certain foreign (American) lobby-groups."[http://www.nu.nl/politiek/2768411/lobbykantoren-vs-steunen-pvv.html 'Lobbykantoren VS steunen PVV']" (in Dutch), ''[[NU.nl]]'', 2012. According to [[Reuters]], [[Daniel Pipes|Daniel Pipes']] [[Middle East Forum]] paid for the trials and security of Geert Wilders and [[David Horowitz]] paid Wilders "a good fee" for two speeches given in the US.Anthony Deutsch & Mark Hosenball, "[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/10/us-dutch-wilders-us-idUSBRE8890Q820120910 Exclusive: U.S. groups helped fund Dutch anti-Islam politician Wilders]", ''[[Reuters]]'', 2012."[http://vorige.nrc.nl/binnenland/article2544752.ece/Partners_Wilders_in_VS_verdienen_aan_acties_tegen_moslimextremisme Partners Wilders in VS verdienen aan acties tegen moslimextremisme]" {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111012085802/http://vorige.nrc.nl/binnenland/article2544752.ece/Partners_Wilders_in_VS_verdienen_aan_acties_tegen_moslimextremisme |date=12 October 2011 }} (in Dutch), ''[[NRC Handelsblad]]'', 2010. Since 2013, Dutch political parties are required by law to disclose all donations of 4,500 euro or more.Cynthia Kroet, "[http://www.politico.eu/article/geert-wilders-far-right-party-suffers-donation-downturn/ Geert Wilders’ far-right party suffers donation downturn]", ''[[Politico Europe]]'', 2017. Retrieved 8 March 2017. The Party for Freedom disclosed no donations for 2013."[https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/publicaties/2014/10/01/pvv-financieel-verslag-over-2013 Financieel verslag PVV 2013]" (in Dutch), ''[[Government of the Netherlands]]'', 2014. Retrieved 8 March 2017. For 2014 to 2016, the party disclosed a total of 148,391.07 euro in donations from the California-based [[David Horowitz Freedom Center]], a total of 18,700 euro in donations from a private donor in the Netherlands, and a donation of 6,853.70 euro from the New York-based company FOL Inc."[https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/publicaties/2015/09/21/pvv---financieel-verslag-over-2014 Financieel verslag PVV 2014]" (in Dutch), ''[[Government of the Netherlands]]'', 2015. Retrieved 8 March 2017."[https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/publicaties/2016/10/13/financiele-verslagen-over-2015-van-politieke-partijen Financiële verslagen over 2015 van politieke partijen]" (in Dutch), ''[[Government of the Netherlands]]'', 2016. Retrieved 8 March 2017."[https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/publicaties/2017/03/08/overzicht-giften-en-schulden-politieke-partijen-tweede-kamerverkiezingen Overzicht giften en schulden politieke partijen Tweede Kamerverkiezingen]" (in Dutch), ''[[Government of the Netherlands]]'', 2017. Retrieved 8 March 2017. The '''Patient Information Advisory Group''' (PIAG) was established in the [[United Kingdom]] under section 61<ref>[http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2001/10015--g.htm#61 section 61 of the Health and Social Care Act 2001]</ref> of the Health and Social Care Act 2001<ref>[http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2001/20010015.htm Health and Social Care Act 2001]</ref> and the Patient Information Advisory Group (Establishment) Regulations 2001<ref>[http://www.opsi.gov.uk/si/si2001/20012836.htm Statutory Instrument 2001 No. 2836: Patient Information Advisory Group (Establishment) Regulations 2001]</ref> to provide advice on issues of national significance involving the use of patient information and to oversee arrangements created under section 60<ref>[http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2001/10015--g.htm#60 Section 60 of the Health and Social Care Act 2001]</ref> of the Act. Its membership was drawn from patient groups, health care professionals and regulatory bodies. Following the implementation of the Health and Social Care Act 2008,<ref>[http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2008/pdf/ukpga_20080014_en.pdf Health and Social Care Act 2008]</ref> PIAG was abolished and its responsibilities transferred to a new body, the [[National Information Governance Board for Health and Social Care]], with effect from January 2009.
==Terms of reference==
The terms of reference for the PIAG were to:
#Advise the [[Secretary of State for Health|Secretary of State]] on use of powers provided by section 60 of the Health and Social Care Act 2001, and in particular on: #*applications and proposals for use of these powers; #*draft regulations made under s60(1) of the Act; #*proposals to vary or revoke such regulations following the [[Secretary of State for Health|Secretary of State]]'s required annual review of existing provisions. #Advise the [[Secretary of State for Health|Secretary of State]] on key issues, particularly those of national significance, relating to the processing of patient information.
==Legal framework==
Section 60 of the Health and Social Care Act 2001 (subsequently Section 251 of the NHS Act 2006) provided a power to ensure that patient identifiable information needed to support essential [[National Health Service|NHS]] activity could be used without the consent of patients. The power could only be used to support medical purposes that were in the interests of patients or the wider public, where consent was not a [[wikt:practicable|practicable]] alternative and where [[anonymised]] information would not suffice. It was intended largely as a transitional measure whilst consent or anonymisation procedures were developed, and this was reinforced by the need to review each use of the power annually.
This was developed to cover situations where [[informed consent]] could not be obtained, for example research projects of such a size as to make contacting each patient impracticable, where the public good derived from the research was agreed to outweigh the individual [[right to privacy]].
==References==
{{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070426110229/http://www.advisorybodies.doh.gov.uk/piag/ PIAG website] *[http://www.nigb.nhs.uk NIGB website] *[http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Policyandguidance/Informationpolicy/Patientconfidentialityandcaldicottguardians Department of Health: Patient confidentiality and access to health records] *[http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Policyandguidance/Informationpolicy/Patientconfidentialityandcaldicottguardians/DH_4100550 Department of Health: NHS confidentiality code of practice] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070928164020/http://www.ico.gov.uk/upload/documents/library/data_protection/practical_application/health_data_-_use_and_disclosure001.pdf Information Commissioner: Use and disclosure of health data] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080413070532/http://www.nres.npsa.nhs.uk/ National Research Ethics Service]
[[Category:National Health Service]]

{{For|wearing red on Fridays in support of Canadian troops|Support our troops#Red Friday}} {{one source|date=November 2017}} On Friday 31 July 1925 the [[Conservative Government 1924–1929|British government]] agreed to the demands of the [[Miners Federation of Great Britain]] to provide a subsidy to the mining industry to maintain miners' wages. The ''[[Daily Herald (UK newspaper)|Daily Herald]]'' called this day '''Red Friday'''; a union defeat four years earlier had been called "[[Black Friday (1921)|Black Friday]]".<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw |1975 |pp= 122–7}}</ref> The [[1926 United Kingdom general strike|1926 General Strike]] followed nine months later.
==Background== There had been a long history of labour unrest in the [[Great Britain|British]] [[Coal mining in the United Kingdom|coal mining]] industry. A triple alliance had been formed in 1914 of the Miners Federation, the [[Transport and General Workers Union]] and the [[National Union of Railwaymen]], for mutual support in trade disputes, but had been unable to undertake united action due to [[World War I]]. In 1916, at the height of [[World War I]], [[David Lloyd George|Lloyd George's]] [[United Kingdom coalition government (1916–1922)|government]] had taken control of the industry, but with [[inflation]] the purchasing power of miners' wages had fallen.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw |1975 |pp= 53–7}}</ref>
After the war government control was relaxed, and the triple alliance was revived. In 1919, as a conciliatory measure, the government appointed a [[royal commission]] to investigate the industry under [[John Sankey, 1st Viscount Sankey|Mr Justice Sankey]], which recommended the nationalisation of mining royalties but did not explain how this would be achieved. The government, citing the lack of unanimity of the commission, declined to implement its report.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw |1975 |pp= 59–64}}</ref> The government responded to a strike by the Yorkshire miners in July 1919 by planning measures to maintain the mines during the strike.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw |1975 |pp= 65–6}}</ref>
In April 1921 the miners went on strike, seeking equalisation of wages between coalfields, but the unity of the triple alliance collapsed, leaving the miners to fight on until hunger drove them back to work on Black Friday, leaving the employers (who had come together in the Mining Association) in control.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw|1975|pp=22–3 82–9}}</ref> There was a small concession to the miners of a temporary subsidy of £10M, but their average pay fell by 30% during 1921.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw |1975 |pp= 88–9}}</ref>
==Red Friday== In April 1925 Britain returned to the [[gold standard]]. This was effectively a revaluation of sterling, and led to deflation in the British economy over the following years. This made it difficult for the coal owners to export coal profitably in the face of resurgent German exports. On 30 June the Mining Association gave notice to terminate the 1924 wage agreement, after which wages would be cut (with no national minimum) and hours increased.<ref>{{harvnb|Renshaw |1975 |pp= 117–8}} </ref> Negotiations took place, but it was soon apparent that, without a subsidy, a strike or lock-out was inevitable. The miners had secured an agreement from the railwaymen that they would not handle coal. This was likely to result in the railway companies sacking those who refused, leading to a railway strike.
The government reviewed emergency arrangements and Prime Minister [[Stanley Baldwin|Baldwin]] concluded, "We were not ready". In consequence the government backed down, and negotiated a subsidy for the coal industry to last nine months to enable the employers to maintain wages and conditions. This cost £23M. It seems that an emergency plan existed on paper, but would require the recruitment of many volunteers to implement it, and the staff did not exist.
==Reaction== The subsidy could only be a temporary measure. The government immediately put in hand measures to be implemented in the event of a general strike, which seemed inevitable when the subsidy ended.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * Patrick Renshaw, ''The General Strike'' (Eyre Methuen, London, 1975).
